MINUTES OF THE SPECIAL MEETING OF THE COUNCIL OF THE CORPORATION OF THE TOWN OF WHITBY HELD ON MONDAY, MARCH 19, 2012 AT THE HOUR OF 6:00 P.M. IN THE MEETING HALL OF THE WHITBY MUNICIPAL BUILDING PRESENT: Mayor Perkins Mayor Perkins in the Chair Councillor Coe Councillor Drumm Councillor Emm Councillor Hanson Councillor Mitchell Councillor Montague Councillor Roy STAFF PRESENT: R. Petrie, Chief Administrative Officer S. Beale, Commissioner of Public Works K.R. Nix, Commissioner of Corporate Services/Treasurer B. Short, Commissioner of Planning D. Wilcox, Town Clerk M. Pettit, Deputy Clerk 1. DISCLOSURES OF INTEREST There were no disclosures of interest noted. 2. ITEM FOR CONSIDERATION BY COUNCIL IN COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE (per Council Resolution No. 253-08) 2.1 Planning Report, Item PL 21-12 Re: Official Plan Review – Public Meeting – Draft Policy Discussion Papers – (OPA-2007-W/04) RESOLUTION NO. 68-12 MOVED by Councillor Mitchell Seconded by Councillor Montague That Council resolve itself into Committee of the Whole with Councillor Coe in the Chair to consider Planning Report, Item PL 21-12, Official Plan Review – Public Meeting – Draft Policy Discussion Papers – (OPA-2007- W/04). CARRIED Councillor Coe in the Chair. The Town Clerk advised members of the audience on the process of Public Meetings.  MINUTES OF THE SPECIAL MEETING OF THE COUNCIL OF THE CORPORATION OF THE TOWN OF WHITBY HELD ON MONDAY, MARCH 19, 2012 AT THE HOUR OF 6:00 P.M. IN THE MEETING HALL OF THE WHITBY MUNICIPAL BUILDING R. Short, Commissioner of Planning introduced the report and provided a synopsis of the process undertaken to date. Chair Coe declared the meeting to be a public meeting and invited submissions from the audience. Robert Nixon, 9190 Ashburn Road, appeared before Committee of the Whole, and provided a brief review of the milestones and decisions since the Official Plan Review had been undertaken. Mr. Nixon expressed objections over the urban boundary expansion in North Whitby, and stated that the Ministry has made no decision on the boundary expansion and should therefore not be included in the Official Plan Review being considered. Mr. Nixon also expressed concern regarding the failure of the Official Plan Review to fully incorporate the direction of the OPA 90 Intensification Plan that was approved by Town of Whitby Council in 2011 and that the continuing exploitation of farmlands and prime agricultural land to accommodate more residential lands would be detrimental to the overall health of the community. David Axhorn, 7421 Cochrane Street, appeared before Committee of the Whole, and enquired why Lakeridge Road or other routes could not be used for the purpose of a proposed parkway as this would be less disruptive to residents. Mr. Axhorn also enquired why a parkway would be required further north than Highway 407 and why there is a need for so much land for the road allowance. Mr. Axhorn advised in his opinion this parkway is not necessary. R. Petrie, Chief Administrative Officer advised that the map included in the Plan is conceptual in nature and that there is no plan to have a 400 foot road allowance to accommodate the proposed parkway. Mr. Petrie also advised that the Transportation Master Plan was completed a few years ago through a public process, however given the number of residents who were not aware of this, he recommends that further public consultation with the community be undertaken to review what the future transportation needs are in Brooklin, what alternative options are to be investigated and evaluated to determine the preferred solution. Mr. Petrie advised that the Public Works Department would schedule a public meeting in this regard for the fall of this year and that all those residents who signed in tonight or whose lands would be affected by the proposed parkway would be notified by mail of the meeting date and time. Ian Finch, 7621 Cochrane Street, appeared before Committee of the Whole, and enquired how long the environmental assessment would take and noted that property owners would be unable to sell while their residences were tied up waiting for the study to be completed, which would reduce the value of their homes. Mr. Finch enquired if the Town of  MINUTES OF THE SPECIAL MEETING OF THE COUNCIL OF THE CORPORATION OF THE TOWN OF WHITBY HELD ON MONDAY, MARCH 19, 2012 AT THE HOUR OF 6:00 P.M. IN THE MEETING HALL OF THE WHITBY MUNICIPAL BUILDING Whitby would be compensating owners for this inconvenience. Robin Mason, 7600 Cedarbrook Trail, appeared before Committee of the Whole, and enquired if the meeting in the fall was just postponing the matter and asked for clarification on whether this was considered the default position until such time as the review was completed. Mr. Mason advised he was supportive of getting truck traffic off Highway 12 but was not convinced this was the optimum solution to achieve this as it just relocates the problem to another area of town. R.. Petrie, Chief Administrative Officer advised that the meeting in the fall would cover not just the proposed parkway location but would include a review of all options for the area. Sharon Johnson, 340 Watson Street, #418, appeared before Committee of the Whole, and advised that transportation studies had been completed years ago and do not appear to be working as the current transportation system is insufficient for the volume of traffic. Ms. Johnson enquired if the study was predicting far enough in the future and if there were contingencies in the plan to deal with higher traffic volumes than anticipated. S. Beale, Commissioner of Public Works advised that the Transportation Master Plan was based on a 2031 horizon and the plan would be reviewed every five to ten years to determine if adjustments were required. Robert Walton, 7491 Cochrane Street, appeared before Committee of the Whole, and advised that the proposed parkway has been talked about for decades but nothing has ever happened. Mr. Walton expressed concerns that the proposed parkway location would have a detrimental affect on the property value of resident's homes and queried why he and other residents were not notified by personal mail of the meeting. Mr. Walton suggested that other options be reviewed. R. Petrie, Chief Administrative Officer, advised that the purpose of tonight's meeting was not to discuss the parkway, but to review the Official Plan Discussion papers. Mr. Petrie advised that the study is not yet underway for the proposed parkway but once it is underway all property owners affected would be notified through personal mail. Paul Duggan, 7365 Country Lane, appeared before Committee of the Whole, and advised that he concurs with the previous speakers and that he was also unaware of the proposed parkway. Mr. Duggan advised he is not opposed to progress but objects to having his property kept in a holding pattern until a definite location for the parkway is determined.  MINUTES OF THE SPECIAL MEETING OF THE COUNCIL OF THE CORPORATION OF THE TOWN OF WHITBY HELD ON MONDAY, MARCH 19, 2012 AT THE HOUR OF 6:00 P.M. IN THE MEETING HALL OF THE WHITBY MUNICIPAL BUILDING Phil Nicols, 17 Springsyde Street, appeared before Committee of the Whole, and advised that his parcel of land at the corner of Lakeridge Road/Highway 2, has been in his family's possession for fifty years and many proposals have been put forward throughout the years however none have ever come to fruition. Mr. Nicols questioned the Provincial plans to have an interchange at Lakeridge Road/Highway 401 and why this was not being pursued. B. Short, Commissioner of Planning, advised that the subject property is designated for employment purposes and this will be held in abeyance until ROPA 128 is settled. Mr. Short advised that Mr. Nicols could get further information by contacting Planning staff. Karen and Paul Pearson, 7460 Country Lane, appeared before Committee of the Whole, and advised he was unaware where the proposed parkway was going to be built and that this would jeopardize any chances of selling his home, should he wish to do so in the future. Mr. Pearson advised he was unaware the meeting was occurring tonight and enquired why an alternate route further to the north could not be found that would lessen the impact on existing property owners. R. Petrie, Chief Administrative Officer, advised that the meeting taking place in the fall would include a review to determine if the parkway was necessary and review alternatives to see if there was a better option. This process would include public participation throughout and should a better solution be determined it would be included into the Official Plan. Lydia Hartley, 7492 Ashburn Road, appeared before Committee of the Whole, and advised she firmly believes that this proposed parkway drawn on the plan will definitely affect property values and enquired if it could be removed from the drawings until the study and the review of all alternatives has been completed. R. Petrie, Chief Administrative Officer, advised that the line does not exist in the Town's existing Official Plan at this point in time and that the best thing we can do is proceed with the study to determine a location for the proposed parkway. Sophie Bigham, 7425 Country Lane, appeared before Committee of the Whole, and enquired why she was not notified of the proposed parkway intersecting her lands as indicated on the map. Ms. Bigham feels that she cannot continue to make any improvements or changes to her home or property until this matter is settled and enquired how long it would be before residents had a firm answer on the exact location of the proposed parkway. S. Beale, Commissioner of Public Works, advised that the study is anticipated to begin in the fall and would take approximately 12-14 months to complete, however the answers to whether the parkway was even needed and the location would be determined at 6-8 months from study commencement. The requirements for the study would be a very formal public process including a Terms of Reference and an environmental assessment with the Ministry of Environment giving final approval before proceeding. Ms. Beale advised that the development of a  MINUTES OF THE SPECIAL MEETING OF THE COUNCIL OF THE CORPORATION OF THE TOWN OF WHITBY HELD ON MONDAY, MARCH 19, 2012 AT THE HOUR OF 6:00 P.M. IN THE MEETING HALL OF THE WHITBY MUNICIPAL BUILDING Community Advisory Committee specifically dedicated to this subject is likely to be created in order to assist with the process. Carmen Duggan, 7365 Country Lane, appeared before Committee of the Whole, and advised that in her opinion the proposed parkway was not a solution but part of the problem of over development of the area particularly if the urban boundaries are expanded north of Columbus Road. Ms. Duggan advised she was not aware of any public process taking place during the consideration of the Transportation Master Plan and enquired if residents would have any say in the future placement of the parkway. R. Petrie, Chief Administrative Officer, advised that there is a very formal public process through the Ministry of Environment and that Council and Town staff will be very interested in hearing what residents' suggestions are for alternative locations of the parkway. Angelina Mason, 7600 Cedarbrook Trail, appeared before Committee of the Whole, and advised that when her family purchased their property they were of the understanding that this was a protected area that would not allow this kind of development and enquired if CLOCA had been involved in the decision. Ms. Mason enquired if the route shown would be the final one chosen unless another route was determined. S Beale, Commissioner of Public Works, advised that CLOCA was one of the reviewing agencies of the Transportation Master Plan as well as the Ministry of Environment and the Ministry of Transportation, who all reviewed and provided comment on the plan prior to it being approved at Council. Ms. Beale commented that the route planning of the corridor is part of the special study and that when the findings are completed there would need to be a review. Ms. Beale advised that as part of the class environmental assessment there is always the option to do nothing, or they could accept a portion of the proposed parkway route or use another alternative altogether. Marie Cockburn, 985 Brawley Road, Ashburn, appeared before Committee of the Whole, and advised she attended all the workshops last year and doesn't recall any mention of a proposed parkway in the Brooklin area. S. Beale, Commissioner of Public Works, advised that the Transportation Master Plan public meetings were a couple of years ago and separate and distinct from the Official Plan public workshops that were held last year. Robin Mason, 7600 Cedarbrook Trail, suggested that Council put forward a resolution removing the proposed parkway from the Transportation Master Plan and the Official Plan review in favour of a more general statement for getting heavy truck traffic off of Highway 12. R. Petrie, Chief Administrative Officer, advised that the proposed parkway would always be in the public realm as noted in the Transportation Master Plan subject to further study and staff would have to review and report back on the best  MINUTES OF THE SPECIAL MEETING OF THE COUNCIL OF THE CORPORATION OF THE TOWN OF WHITBY HELD ON MONDAY, MARCH 19, 2012 AT THE HOUR OF 6:00 P.M. IN THE MEETING HALL OF THE WHITBY MUNICIPAL BUILDING way to deal with the issues raised tonight. Barry Hum, 87 Tormina Boulevard, appeared before Committee of the Whole, and commented specifically in regard to the Official Plan, suggesting that benchmarks should be determined to review and measure how well we are doing in meeting the goals of the Official Plan, that partnerships be formed with the Boards of Education, business development communities, Durham College and UOIT and hospitals as examples in order to make the best use of community infrastructure. Mr. Hum also suggested the implementation of fibre optic communications throughout the Town to increase communication which could lessen the need for expanded transportation routes. Mayor Perkins advised that the Town of Whitby is the lower tier of the two tier structure and that not all functions are the sole responsibility of the Town. The Region is looking into fibre optics for Durham Region and the hospital falls under the jurisdiction and authority of the Province. B. Short, Commissioner of Planning, advised that benchmarks are set out under the Planning Act as well as some internally developed benchmarks and that the Town is moving forward in this direction. Matthew Cory, of Malone Given Parsons, appeared before Committee of the Whole, on behalf of the Brooklin North Land Owners group, and advised that he did appear at the public meetings when the Transportation Master Plan was being considered and that they encouraged the Town to take a longer term horizon of 50 years at that time and when looking at the arterial parkway that other alternatives be looked at by considering an option that made the most use of existing infrastructure. Mr. Cory advised that they believe that planning of the area done over the long term and determination of land uses should be undertaken simultaneously with the planning of the road system. Mr. Cory advised that a clear definition of environmental features and policies is required as the environmental assessment process is often delayed when these have not been determined. Mr. Cory advised that the group has not submitted their written comments as of this date but intend to do so very shortly. B. Short, Commissioner of Planning, advised that they have definitions in terms of looking at natural heritage features and that this technical exercise can be advanced as the Region has undertaken an environment first approach in other instances. Geoff Nova, 7505 Cedarbrook Trail, appeared before Committee of the Whole, and advised they had been told the study area is due to a need for more transportation and that the line as it is currently drawn dissects his property. Mr. Nova suggested that the study be completed first and then come back to residents who may or may not be affected but in the interim remove the line from the map. There were no further public submissions. Chair Coe closed the public  MINUTES OF THE SPECIAL MEETING OF THE COUNCIL OF THE CORPORATION OF THE TOWN OF WHITBY HELD ON MONDAY, MARCH 19, 2012 AT THE HOUR OF 6:00 P.M. IN THE MEETING HALL OF THE WHITBY MUNICIPAL BUILDING meeting. A detailed question and answer period ensued specifically in regard to the comments made by residents this evening, the next steps in the process, the opportunity for a Community Advisory Committee to be established, the need to determine the best viable option that addresses community concerns and the importance and method to be used to notify residents of future meetings on the subject matter. 2.1 Planning Report, Item PL 21-12 Re: Official Plan Review – Public Meeting – Draft Policy Discussion Papers - (OPA-2007-W/04) RECOMMENDATION: MOVED by Councillor Drumm 1. That Planning Report PL 21-12 be received for information; and 2. That comment provided at this Public Meeting be considered along with the written submissions received from the public and stakeholders as part of the comment period for the draft Policy Discussion Papers; and 3. That a Final Directions Paper be prepared by Meridian Planning Consultants with consideration for the comments and feedback received from the public and stakeholders and presented. CARRIED MOVED by Councillor Coe Seconded by Councillor Emm That Council rise and ratify the actions from Committee of the Whole. CARRIED Mayor Perkins resumed the Chair. 4. CONFIRMATORY BY-LAW NO. 6596-12 RESOLUTION NO. 69-12 MOVED by Councillor Coe seconded by Councillor Emm that leave be granted to introduce a by-law and to dispense with the reading of the by-law by the Clerk to confirm the proceedings of the Council of the Town of Whitby at its special meeting held on March 19th, 2012 and that the same be considered read a first, second and third time and finally passed and that the Mayor and the Clerk sign the same and the Seal of the Corporation be thereto affixed. CARRIED By-law No. 6596-12 considered read a first, second and third time and finally  MINUTES OF THE SPECIAL MEETING OF THE COUNCIL OF THE CORPORATION OF THE TOWN OF WHITBY HELD ON MONDAY, MARCH 19, 2012 AT THE HOUR OF 6:00 P.M. IN THE MEETING HALL OF THE WHITBY MUNICIPAL BUILDING passed. 5. ADJOURNMENT RESOLUTION NO. 70-12 MOVED by Councillor Emm Seconded by Councillor Coe That the meeting be adjourned. CARRIED The meeting adjourned at 8:40 p.m. Debi A. Wilcox, Town Clerk Patricia Perkins, Mayor

MINUTES OF A SPECIAL MEETING OF THE COUNCIL OF THE CORPORATION OF THE TOWN OF WHITBY HELD ON MONDAY, JANUARY 10, 2011 AT THE HOUR OF 6:45 P.M. IN COMMITTEE ROOM ONE OF THE WHITBY MUNICIPAL BUILDING PRESENT: Mayor Perkins Mayor Perkins in the Chair Councillor Coe Councillor Drumm Councillor Emm Councillor Hanson Councillor Mitchell Councillor Montague Councillor Roy ABSENT: Councillor Drumm Councillor Roy STAFF PRESENT: R. Petrie, Chief Administrative Officer P. LeBel, Director, Community & Marketing Services S. Edwards, Manager of Parks, Marina, Long Range Planning, Tourism & Culture D. Wilcox, Town Clerk 1. DISCLOSURES OF INTEREST There were no disclosures of interested noted. 2. ITEM FOR CONSIDERATION 2.1 Community & Marketing Services Report, Item CMS 5-11 Re: Canada-Ontario Infrastructure Projects - RinC and ISF Extension Request Robert Petrie, Chief Administrative Officer, introduced the report. P. LeBel, Director of Community & Marketing Services, briefly outlined the contents of Report CMS 5-11. A question and answer period ensued. RESOLUTION NO. 1-11 MOVED by Councillor Mitchell Seconded by Councillor Montague 1. That Council approve the following resolution, a requirement of the Government of Canada and the Province of Ontario for continued Federal-Provincial funding of the approved Canada-Ontario Infrastructure Stimulus (ISF) funded projects and the Recreational Infrastructure Canada/Ontario (RInC) funded projects that will extend construction beyond March 31, 2011;  MINUTES OF A SPECIAL MEETING OF THE COUNCIL OF THE CORPORATION OF THE TOWN OF WHITBY HELD ON MONDAY, JANUARY 10, 2011 AT THE HOUR OF 6:45 P.M. IN COMMITTEE ROOM ONE OF THE WHITBY MUNICIPAL BUILDING WHEREAS the Federal and Provincial Governments are providing a one time extension of the deadline for funding of projects under the Infrastructure Stimulus Fund and the Recreational Infrastructure Canada/Ontario Program from March 31, 2011 to October 2011; AND WHEREAS all funding from the Government of Canada and Ontario will cease after October 31, 2011; AND WHEREAS the Town of Whitby has asked the Provincial Government for an extension to Federal and Provincial funding to October 31, 2011 for the following projects: Program Project Number Project Title Total Eligible Cost RInC R1881 Rehabilitation of Iroquois Park Sports Centre $3,175,000 RInC R1884 Redevelopment of Peel Park $1,610,000 ISF ISF 1807 Anne Ottenbrite Pool – Renovations and Addition $3,500,000 NOW THEREFORE IT BE RESOLVED that the Town of Whitby attests it will continue to contribute its share of the required funding for the aforementioned projects; AND BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that actual claims for all eligible costs incurred by March 31, 2011 for the aforementioned projects must be and will be submitted no later than April 30, 2011; AND BE IT FURTHER RESOLVED that the Town of Whitby will ensure that the projects will be completed and accepts responsibility for any costs incurred beyond October 31, 2011. 2. That a copy of the Council resolution and staff report be forwarded by the Clerk to the Canada-Ontario Infrastructure Secretariat, Ministry of Tourism and Culture – RInC Secretariat, and Ministry of Agriculture, Economic Development Division of Food and Rural Affairs (ISF Projects); and, 3. That the Mayor and Clerk be authorized to sign the amended Contribution Agreements with the Federal/Provincial Governments by no later than February 28, 2011. CARRIED 3. CONFIRMATORY BY-LAW NO. 6420-11 RESOLUTION NO. 2-11  MINUTES OF A SPECIAL MEETING OF THE COUNCIL OF THE CORPORATION OF THE TOWN OF WHITBY HELD ON MONDAY, JANUARY 10, 2011 AT THE HOUR OF 6:45 P.M. IN COMMITTEE ROOM ONE OF THE WHITBY MUNICIPAL BUILDING MOVED by Councillor Mitchell, seconded by Councillor Coe, that leave be granted to introduce a by-law and to dispense with the reading of the by-law by the Town Clerk to confirm the proceedings of the Council of the Town of Whitby at its special meeting held on January 10, 2011 and that the same be considered read a first, second and third time and finally passed and that the Mayor and the Town Clerk sign the same and the Seal of the Corporation be thereto affixed. CARRIED 4. ADJOURNMENT RESOLUTION NO. 3-11 MOVED by Councillor Coe Seconded by Councillor Hanson That the meeting be adjourned. CARRIED The meeting adjourned at 6:56 p.m. Debi A. Wilcox, Town Clerk Patricia Perkins, Mayor

DELEGATIONS/PRESENTATIONS    3.1  Recognition of the Town of Whitby for the iCompass Foundation Award  Representatives from iCompass presented the iCompass Foundation  Award to the Town of Whitby.  The award recognizes a municipality for  its innovation in technology related to meeting management and for  improving openness and transparency in local government. Mayor  Perkins was joined on the dias by Councillor Drumm, Chair of the Office  of the Town Clerk; Robert Petrie, Chief Administrative Officer; Debi  Wilcox, Town Clerk; Susan Cassel, Legislative Coordinator; and Alex  Richards, Jeremy Bosch, and Paul Blanchet, of iCompass. Mayor  Perkins congratulated the Office of the Town Clerk for their significant  work on this project.    3.2  Bill Little, representing Sancora Ltd. and David Mills, Mills and  Associates  Re: Planning Report, PL 98-13 - Zoning Amendment Application to  remove the Holding (H) Symbol and Site Plan Application - Sancora Ltd.  (Z-10-13, SP-10-13) 66 and 68 Baldwin Street and 11 Price Street  The delegation request was withdrawn.    3.3  Lydia Hartley, representing the Residents Against the Parkway (RAP)  Re: Planning and Public Works Joint Report, PL 96-13 - Recommended  Study Process for Greater Brooklin Comprehensive Secondary Plan  Study  Page 2 of 26  Regular Council Minutes   October 07, 2013 -7:00 PM    Lydia Hartley, representing the Residents Against the Parkway (RAP)  group addressed Council regarding Planning and Public Works Joint  Report, PL 96-13 - Recommended Study Process for Greater Brooklin  Comprehensive Secondary Plan Study. Ms. Hartley commented that  RAP considers the lines of communication have not been clear with  residents in the Brooklin area in relation to the future transportation plan  and proposed major changes that may be the Brooklin Parkway Road.  Ms. Hartley indicated RAP prefers that AECOM fast track the proposed  study regarding the main arteries of transportation in the area with  clearly identified timelines for the review. A question and answer period  ensued regarding the proposed transportation plan and associated  timelines. Members of Council were provided with a written submission  dated October 2, 2013 from the Residents Against Parkway Committee.    3.4  Edie Gomille, Whitby Resident  Re: Chief Administrative Officer Report, CAO 6-13 - Proposed  Discharge of Firearms By-law   Edie Gomille, 759 Cochrane Street, Whitby, addressed Council  regarding public safety with respect to the proposed discharge of  firearms by-law. R. Petrie, Chief Administrative Officer, advised there may be  opportunities to address the larger road issues before the conclusion of  the main plan. It was advised that the timeline for completion will be  confirmed after meetings with the Region of Durham and the Ministry,  bringing some alternatives for the higher order system as soon as  possible.    Resolution No. 406-13    Moved By Councillor Montague   Seconded By Councillor Coe    1. That joint Planning and Public Works Report Item No. PL 96-13 be  received for information;  2. That Council authorize the undertaking and integration of a  Transportation Master Plan with the comprehensive Secondary Plan  study for the Greater Brooklin Area through expanding the scope of  the current Transportation Class Environmental Study for Northwest  Brooklin;  3. That Council endorse the general scope of work and overall study  framework outlined in joint Planning and Public Works Report Item  No. PL 96-13 as the basis for the preparation of a draft Terms of  Reference for the integrated Secondary Plan Study and the  Transportation Master Plan Study, as well as for peer reviews of  background reports, in consultation with other internal Departments  and external agencies;  4. That, notwithstanding the Purchasing Policy, Council authorize staff  to sole source and retain AECOM to undertake a Transportation  Master Plan for the Greater Brooklin Area through an expansion of  the current Northwest Brooklin Class EA; and sole source and retain  AECOM as necessary for peer reviews of background transportation  and civil engineering documents submitted by the Brooklin North  Landowners Group;  5. That, notwithstanding the Purchasing Policy, Council confirm the  authorization to sole source peer review consultants and authorize  staff to sole source and retain a planning consultant and any other  consultants necessary to assist the Town in the preparation of a  Secondary Plan; and  6. That joint Planning and Public Works Report Item No. PL 96-13 and  Council's resolution be forwarded to the members of the Technical  Advisory Committee and the Community Advisory Committee for the  Northwest Brooklin EA Study, the Brooklin North Landowners Group,  the Residents Against the Parkway, the Region of Durham, the  Page 7 of 26  Regular Council Minutes   October 07, 2013 -7:00 PM    Ministry Infrastructure and Renewal; the Ministry of Transportation;  the Ministry of Environment, the Ministry of Natural Resources and  the Ministry of Municipal Affairs and Housing, and commenting  agencies and LACAC Heritage Whitby, Accessibility Advisory  Committee, Sustainability Advisory Committee and Downtown  Brooklin Development Steering Committee. Page 2 of 10  Committee of the Whole Minutes   May 02, 2022 - 7:00 PM    2.3  Steve Edwards and Shawn Shanmuganathan representing 412 Dundas  Developments Limited (Vaultra Storage)  Re: Planning and Development (Planning Services) Department Report,  PDP 28-22  Official Plan and Zoning By-law Amendment Applications, 412 Dundas  Developments Limited (Vaultra Storage), Block 270 on Plan 40M-2647,  West Side of Des Newman Boulevard, File Numbers: DEV-10-21 (OPA- 2021-W/04, Z-07-21)     Refer to Item 4.5, PDP 28-22  Steve Edwards and Shawn Shanmuganathan, representing 412 Dundas  Developments Limited (Vaultra Storage), stated that they had read and  were in support of the Staff recommendation. Mr. Edwards advised that  Vaultra Storage was partnering with Fieldgate Developments to create  the composite employment development as outlined in the Staff report.  He noted the concerns raised by Economic Development Staff about the  initial construction phases only including self-storage facilities and the  possibility that further phases of the development may not be realized.  Mr. Shanmuganathan confirmed that the entire site would be developed  all at once and that it would not be developed in phases. Mr. Edwards  advised that they were available to answer questions.      2.4  Navdeep Nijhawan  Re: Planning and Development (Planning Services) Department Report,  PDP 28-22  Official Plan and Zoning By-law Amendment Applications, 412 Dundas  Developments Limited (Vaultra Storage), Block 270 on Plan 40M-2647,  West Side of Des Newman Boulevard, File Numbers: DEV-10-21 (OPA- 2021-W/04, Z-07-21)    Refer to Item 4.5, PDP 28-22  Navdeep Nijhawan, 27 Edgar Avenue, Richmond Hill, stated that he was  a physician and current partner of the proposed healthcare complex that  was under construction just north of the proposed development, and the  co-owner of the four-acre vacant land located just south of the proposed  development. Mr. Nijhawan advised that the entire area was designated  as Prestige Employment with residential and mixed-use lands  surrounding. He stated that he did not have any objection to the two  multi-use prestige industrial buildings, but that he was opposed to the  rezoning of the land to allow the construction of the four-storey and five  single-storey commercial self-storage facilities. Mr. Nijhawan noted that  when this land was purchased all of the surrounding neighbours  understood that they were purchasing Prestige Employment land which  Page 3 of 10  Committee of the Whole Minutes   May 02, 2022 - 7:00 PM    would have been known by the developers who purchased this land. He  commented on the approval of rezoning of this land being patently unfair  to homeowners and other prestige employment landowners in the area  who would have purchased their properties with a clear understanding  of how their community would be developed. Mr. Nijhawan stated that  having self-storage facilities, no matter how small, was a contravention  of Zoning By-law # 1784, and that previous Council decisions made it  clear that self-storage units were better placed in Industrial Zone areas  separate from Prestige Employment and residential communities. Mr.  Nijhawan noted that the Urban Design Guidelines approved by Council  on April 7, 2016 provided a specific vision for the area that did not  include self-storage units. He stated that self-storage units would not be  the highest or best use of these lands and that they would remove the  vibrancy of the area and effectively create a "dead zone" where people  would come in and out of the area to access their storage unit and  leave. He raised concerns about the storage facilities creating additional  traffic in the residential neighbourhood, noting that they would not  provide any ancillary employment opportunities or generate any  significant revenue for the community, and that there would be a  disproportionate benefit to non-residents of the community. Mr.  Nijhawan raised further concerns about self-storage units exposing the  area to significant risks including criminal behaviour, noting that in 2021  a self-storage facility in Whitby had over 40 break-ins, and that there  were already several dozen storage facilities located within Durham  Region. He noted that this developer has a storage facility located in  Ajax and that it was not located near a residential community or a  Prestige Employment community. Mr. Nijhawan inquired about the  number of storage unit facilities needed in Durham Region. He stated  that the Staff report notes concerns raised by the Region of Durham  about using the proposed site as a self-storage facility indicating that  self-storage facilities typically result in very low employment density  which does not support the Region's goal of achieving increased local  employment for residents and the higher employment densities  expected within designated Prestige Employment areas. Mr. Nijhawan  requested that the Committee reconsider supporting the application to  rezone the land to permit self-storage facilities on the site. He stated  that, while the Staff report recommends approval of the rezoning, there  was a certain intangible effect of having self-storage units in the area  that deters from ensuring that the community can achieve its highest  potential. Mr. Nijhawan advised that the decision that the Committee  makes now would significantly impact the nature of future developments  in the area. He stated that he hoped that the Committee would ensure  that the development of the West Whitby community satisfies the vision  of the original plan. Staff Reports    9.1  Financial Services Department Report, FS 32-22  Re: Building Permit Fees Annual Financial Report 2021  Page 9 of 10  Committee of the Whole Minutes   May 02, 2022 - 7:00 PM    A question and answer period ensued between Members of Committee  and Staff regarding:  • confirmation that the amount of funds in the Building Permit  Reserve Fund would cover two years of operating costs;  • whether there would be a reduction in the building permit fees or  whether funds would be redirected to another reserve fund;  • the possibility of utilizing all reserve funds should the building  permit fees be reduced;  • the possibility of requiring additional Staff resources to manage  building permit applications in the future; and,  • the rationale for the reserve fund target balance of $10.2 million.      Recommendation:    Moved By Councillor Leahy    That Report FS 32-22 regarding Building Permit Fees Annual Financial  Report 2021 be received as information.    Carried  10. category: Active Transportation and Safe Roads Advisory Committee
text: Active Transportation and Safe Roads Advisory Committee Minutes  March 10, 2022 - 4:00 PM  Virtual Meeting           Present:  Ron Lalonde   Sorin Lutz  R. Bruce MacDonald   Matt Parfitt  Peter Phillips, Chair  Mary Jo Sitter   Lewis Williams  Nicola Windrem  Terry Von Zuben     Also Present:  Matt Powers, Senior Manager, Parks, Parks Planning and Culture  Aimee Pugao, Planner II, Parks Planning  Deanna Schlosser, Planner II, Long Range  Chris Potvin, Staff Liaison, Supervisor, Active Transportation  Tara Painchaud, Staff Liaison, Senior Manager, Transportation  Services  Heather Ellis, Council and Committee Coordinator (Recording  Secretary)    Regrets:  Gary Carroll, Vice Chair       Call to Order  1.  Disclosures of Interest    1.1  There were no disclosures of interest.    2.  Approval of Previous Minutes    2.1  Minutes - January 13, 2022      Recommendation:    Moved By Ron Lalonde    That the Active Transportation and Safe Roads Advisory Committee  minutes of January 13, 2022 be approved.   Active Transportation and Safe Roads Advisory Committee Minutes   March 10, 2022 - 4:00 PM      Carried  3.  General Business and Reports    3.1  Federal Active Transportation Fund: Infrastructure Canada Applications  Chris Potvin advised that three Whitby project applications were being  submitted which included:  • the Region of Durham, an application for a number of regional  projects including a few in Whitby;  • the Town of Whitby, a planning application for Bike Month  delivery tools such as outreach and school events, handouts, and  event support; and,  • the Town of Whitby, a capital application for the catwalk bridge at  the boardwalk section of the Waterfront Trail.  Tara Painchaud advised that the Region of Durham requested feedback  from the Town regarding the priority of projects.  Discussion ensued regarding:  • low priority items such as Thickson Road; and,  • high priority items such as the Brock Street rail bridge south of  the Go Station multi use path, and Rossland Road.      3.2  2022 Capital Budget Update  Tara Painchaud provide an update regarding the 2022 Capital Budget  which included:  • construction projects delayed from 2021;  • multi use path and cycling facilities delayed from 2021;  • centre lines and user symbols;  • pedestrian crossovers, traffic calming, traffic signage and  pavement marking initiatives, a traffic signal at Baldwin Street  and Canary Street, and a Pedestrian Traffic Signal at Manning  Road and the Hydro Electric Power Corridor (HEPC) trail;  • data collection such as radar speed feedback, data collection,  and pedestrian/bike counters;  • the sidewalk program; and,  • community projects (construction, rehabilitation, resurfacing, and  widening) such as Gallimere Court to Nichol Park Trail  resurfacing, Waterfront Trail widening and resurfacing, Lynde  Creek Trail rehabilitation, and adding trail rest stops and  benches.  Page 2 of 7  Active Transportation and Safe Roads Advisory Committee Minutes   March 10, 2022 - 4:00 PM    A question and answer period ensued regarding:  • the surface material for the Corbett Creek boardwalk;  • whether the Twin Streams trail would be connected along the  Lynde Creek Trail for pedestrians and cyclists;  • whether the section of the HEPC trail along Crawford Drive would  be reviewed;  • whether the Town was applying to become a silver level Bicycle  Friendly Communty;  • the timeline for extending Bonacord Avenue to Des Newman  Boulevard; and,  • an update for a multi use path and bike lanes on Coronation  Road north of Rossland Road.      3.3  Winter Maintenance of Active Transportation Trails  Hector Moreno provided an update regarding the 2022 Winter Snow  Storm Report which included:  • challenges with snow removal on roads, trails, and accessing  groomed trails due to equipment;  • reviewing the issues and successes of managing the clearing of  snow after the 2022 winter snow storm with stakeholders; and,  • conducting a full review of the trail system to determine best  practices for snow removal of each section.  Discussion ensued regarding:  • trails that were not cleared during the 2022 winter snow storm;  • upgrading groomed Hydro Electric Power Corridor (HEPC) trails  to full plow trails; and,  • an opportunity to form an Active Transportation and Safe Roads  Advisory Subcommittee to provide feedback regarding the review  of the trail system.      3.4  Waterfront Trail Updates: Whitby Harbour Remediation, Department of  Fisheries and Oceans  Matt Powers provided an update regarding the Waterfront Trail which  included remediation on the shore break wall and a partial closure of the  trail.  Discussion ensued regarding:  • the closure status of sections of the Waterfront Trail; and,  • an update on the gate at the bottom of Gordon Street leading into  the Ontario Shores property.      Page 3 of 7  Active Transportation and Safe Roads Advisory Committee Minutes   March 10, 2022 - 4:00 PM    3.5  Bike Month  Chris Potvin provided an update regarding Bike Month activities which  included:  • partnering with Cycle TO and the Region of Durham;  • social media blasts and advertising campaign;  • a request from Members to submit images from previous bike  month activities to build a library of images for the social media  campaign;  • connecting with local schools; and,  • the timeline for Bike Month activities beginning the last week of  May and continuing to the end of June.      3.6  Taunton Road/Cochrane Street Improvements  Chris Potvin provided an update regarding Taunton Road/Cochrane  Street improvements which included:  • ramping the bike lanes off the road and onto sidewalks to tie into  crossrides at the intersection;  • completing road improvements with the development on the  northwest quadrant of Cochrane Street and Taunton Road; and,  • finalizing sidewalk and bike lane designs upon completion of the  development.  A question and answer period ensued regarding:  • whether the crossrides would include signalized heads to support  cyclists; and,  • whether the bikes lanes pertained to the northbound side of  Cochrane Street.      3.7  Active and Sustainable School Travel  Nicola Windrem provided an update on Active and Sustainable School  Travel which included:  • three active and sustainable school travel events hosted by  schools including walk and roll, winter walk day, and bike month;  • cycling statistics such as 73% of cycling accidents involve a  motor vehicle, 32% of those cyclists were not wearing helmets,  and 44% of those cyclists were under the age of 20;  • the role of the School Travel Planning (STP);  • the Bicycle Education and Skills Training (BEST) program in  Manitoba provided to grade 4 through to grade 8 students; and,  • cycling training provided through the BEST program, such as bike  maintenance, hand signals, lane positioning, and shoulder  checking.  Page 4 of 7  Active Transportation and Safe Roads Advisory Committee Minutes   March 10, 2022 - 4:00 PM    A brief question and answer period ensued regarding schools within the  Town of Whitby that may be interested in participating in a similar  program.      3.8  Downtown Whitby Secondary Plan  Note: This item was deferred to the next Active Transportation and Safe  Roads Advisory Committee meeting.      3.9  EcoCounter Data Report  Note: This item was deferred to the next Active Transportation and Safe  Roads Advisory Committee meeting.      3.10 Share the Road Summit  Ron Lalonde advised that the Share the Road Summit would be held  virtually and that Peter Phillips would attend on behalf of the Active  Transportation and Safe Roads Advisory Committee.      3.11 Development Subcommittee Update  Mary Jo Sitter provided an update regarding development plans  reviewed by the Development Subcommittee which included:  • a new site building at 111 Consumers Drive;  • a proposed condominium/townhouse development at the  southeast corner of Hopkins Street and Nichol Avenue;  • a three building condominium development at 840 Rossland  Road;  • a townhouse development at 7500 Duffs Road;  • a draft plan of subdivision at 7585 Duffs Road; and,  • a draft plan of subdivision at 7362 and 7432 Ashburn Road.      3.12 Durham Active Transportation Committee Update  Ron Lalonde provided an update regarding the Durham Active  Transportation Committee. Mr. Lalonde noted the 12 kilometres of  cycling routes approved by the Region of Durham, signing and  wayfinding throughout the Region, and the expansion of the assisted  school program in the Region's 2022 Budget. He further stated that an  e-scooter update would be discussed at the March 29, 2022 Durham  Active Transportation Committee meeting.    4.  Council Update  Page 5 of 7  Active Transportation and Safe Roads Advisory Committee Minutes   March 10, 2022 - 4:00 PM      4.1  There was no Council update.    5.  Other Business    5.1  Trail Clean-up  Ron Lalonde stated that a Cullen Central Park Trail clean up was taking  place on April 2, 2022 at 9:00 a.m.      5.2  Special Events  Tara Painchaud stated that Council approved the 2022 to 2025 Special  Events Strategy and that the Town would be hosting in person events.  Ms. Painchaud further stated that the Active Whitby event was  tentatively scheduled for May 2022 and that Manning Road between  Brock Street and Garden Street would be closed for the event.      5.3  Rail Structure  Tara Painchaud advised that the Region of Durham was finalizing the  design for the rail structure between Rossland Road and Bonacord  Avenue. Ms. Painchaud stated that the design would included a multi  use path on both sides of the structure and an on-road bike lane would  ramp up onto the multi use path on the bridge deck. She further stated  that the sidewalk would also funnel into the multi use path and then  separate out again on the opposite side of the bridge.      5.4  Brock Street Structure  Tara Painchaud provided an update regarding the Brock Street structure  crossing over Pringle Creek, south of Victoria Street. Ms. Painchaud  stated that the Town was waiting for final designs. She further stated  that Brock Street and the Waterfront Trail would be closed during  construction and a detour was being reviewed included using Harbour  Street to Watson Street.    6.  Next Meeting    6.1  Thursday, May 12, 2022 - 4:00 p.m.  Virtual Meeting    7.  Adjournment    7.1  Motion to Adjourn    Page 6 of 7  Active Transportation and Safe Roads Advisory Committee Minutes   March 10, 2022 - 4:00 PM      Recommendation:    Moved By Ron Lalonde    That the meeting adjourn.    Carried    The meeting adjourned at 5:55 p.m.       Note: These minutes were approved by the Active Transportation and Safe  Roads Advisory Committee on May 12, 2022.  Page 7 of 7

Carried  2.  In Camera Matters     Special Council Minutes   April 28, 2014 - 5:00 PM    2.1  Community and Marketing Services Department Confidential Report,  CMS 26-14  Re: R.A. Sennett Public School      This portion of the meeting was closed to the public. [Refer to the In- Camera minutes of the meeting - Town Clerk has custody and control.]    Resolution # 166-14    Moved By Councillor Coe  Seconded By Councillor Drumm    That Council rise and ratify the recommendations from the In-Camera  session of the Special Meeting of Council.    Carried  3.  Confirmatory By-Law    3.1  Confirmatory By-law    Resolution # 167-14    Moved By Councillor Emm  Seconded By Councillor Coe    That leave be granted to introduce a by-law and to dispense with the  reading of the by-law by the Clerk to confirm the proceedings of the  Council of the Town of Whitby at its special meeting held on April 28,  2014, and that the Mayor and the Clerk sign the same and the Seal of  the Corporation be thereto affixed.    Carried  4.  Adjournment    4.1  Motion to Adjourn    Resolution # 168-14    Moved By Councillor Coe  Seconded By Councillor Montague    Page 2 of 3  Special Council Minutes   April 28, 2014 - 5:00 PM    That the meeting be adjourned. 1    Whitby Sustainability Advisory Committee Minutes    December 6, 2023, 7:00 p.m.  Virtual Meeting    Present:  Wenda Abel  Brian Kelly  Patti Mavins  Catherine Philogene  Bryan Widner, Chair  Bob Willard  Zartasha Zainab  Regrets:  Sara Best, Vice-Chair  Andrea Cecchetto  Janet Dignem  Anahita Jami  Also Present:  Sarah Shields, Staff Liaison, Project Manager, Sustainability and  Climate Change  Junaid Khan, Project Manager, Sustainability and Climate  Change  Kristin Palilionis, Staff Liaison, Climate Change Coordinator  Laura MacDougall, Council and Committee Coordinator  Heather Ellis, Council and Committee Coordinator (Recording  Secretary)  _____________________________________________________________________    1.  Call to Order  2.  Declarations of Conflict of Interest  There were no declarations of conflict of interest.  3.  Approval of Previous Minutes  Moved by Brian Kelly  That the Whitby Sustainability Advisory Committee minutes of October 4, 2023  be approved.       2  Carried    4.  Presentations  4.1  Brian Kelly, Member, Whitby Sustainability Advisory Committee  Re: The Kelly Household's Journey Towards Zero Carbon and  Sustainability Finance Forum  Brian Kelly provided a presentation regarding The Kelly Household's  Journey Towards Zero Carbon and Sustainability Finance Forum.  Highlights of the presentation included:   detailed information about Step 1: New House Retrofit, Step 2:  Electric Vehicle, Step 3: Photovoltaic System (PV), Step 4: Heat  Pump, and Step 5: Heat Pump Water Heater;   details about the costs and saving related to the electric vehicle  purchased by The Kelly Household, as well as the expenditures,  rebates, and savings for the photovoltaic system and the heat  pump;   information about the carbon fee-bate; and,   lessons learned throughout the process.  A question and answer period ensued regarding:   the possibility of receiving monetary reimbursement for the furnace  and air conditioner upon their removal;   whether the existing air ducts in the house were used for the  installation of the new heat pump; and,   justification for choosing an air source versus a ground source heat  pump.  Brian Kelly provided an overview and the objective of the Sustainability  Finance Forum conference that took place in Ottawa.  5.  Delegations  There were no delegations.  6.  General Business and Reports  6.1  Introductions of New Members       3  Bryan Widner introduced and welcomed Bob Willard and Zartasha Zainab  to the Committee.  6.2  Project Planning and Work Plan Review  Discussion ensued regarding:   the status of the work plan and annual updates to the work plan;  and,   the timeline to finalize the work plan.  6.3  2024 Sustainability Events  Sarah Shields provided an overview of opportunities for sustainability  events in 2024.   Discussion ensued regarding:   a Pollinator Maintenance Event and Invasive Species Poll;   announcing the tree selected through the Town's Official Tree  Campaign Survey; and,   involving and educating the public about sustainable and/or rain  gardens by allowing the public to participate in the planting and  maintenance of municipal pollinator and sustainable gardens.  7.  Correspondence  There was no correspondence.  8.  Council Update  There was no Council update.  9.  Other Business  9.1  Multi-Residential Composting Pilot Project  Wenda Abel stated that the Sail Winds Condo in Port Whitby was being  considered to participate in a Multi-Residential Composting Pilot Project.  9.2  Social Media Posts  Catherine Philogene advised that the Town recently posted social media  content about the amount of salt being used to maintain municipal roads  during the winter. Ms. Philogene stated that the post may have been  perceived by some as boasting about the use of salt without consideration  for significant environmental consequences. She noted that the Town       4  should be more aware about how posts related to sustainability may be  perceived.  10.  Next Meeting  Wednesday, January 3, 2024 - 7:00 p.m.  11.  Adjournment  Moved by Catherine Philogene  That the meeting adjourn.  Carried  The meeting adjourned at 8:22 p.m.  Note: These minutes were approved by the Whitby Sustainability Advisory  Committee on January 3, 2024.

1    Committee of the Whole Minutes    May 5, 2025, 7:00 p.m.  Council Chambers  Whitby Town Hall    Present:  Councillor Bozinovski  Councillor Cardwell  Councillor Leahy (Virtual Attendance)  Councillor Lundquist  Councillor Mulcahy  Councillor Shahid  Councillor Yamada (Virtual Attendance)  Regrets:  Mayor Roy  Councillor Lee  Also Present:  M. Gaskell, Chief Administrative Officer  M. Hickey, Fire Chief  S. Klein, Deputy Chief Administrative Officer  J. Long, Head of Organizational Effectiveness  J. Romano, Commissioner of Community Services  F. Santaguida, Commissioner of Legal and Enforcement  Services/Town Solicitor  R. Saunders, Commissioner of Planning and Development  F. Wong, Commissioner of Financial Services/Treasurer  M. Dodge, Executive Advisor to the Mayor  C. Harris, Town Clerk  K. Narraway, Sr. Manager of Legislative Services/Deputy Clerk   L. MacDougall, Council and Committee Coordinator (Recording  Secretary)  _____________________________________________________________________    1.  Call To Order: The Mayor  2.  Call of the Roll: The Clerk       2  3.  Declarations of Conflict of Interest  There were no declarations of conflict of interest.  4.  Consent Agenda  5.  Planning and Development  Councillor Shahid assumed the Chair.  5.1  Presentations  There were no presentations.  5.2  Delegations  5.2.1 Jack Wong representing Mattamy (Thickson) Limited (In-Person  Attendance)  Re: PDP 22-25, Planning and Development (Planning Services)  Department Report  Draft Plan of Subdivision and Zoning By-law Amendment  Applications, Mattamy (Thickson) Limited, File Number: DEV-02-22  (SW-2022-01 and Z-02-22)    Refer to Item 5.4.1, PDP 22-25  Jack Wong, representing Mattamy (Thickson) Limited, appeared  before the Committee and stated that he supported the Staff  recommendation and was available to answer questions.  A brief question and answer period ensued between Members of  Committee and Mr. Wong regarding how the proposed  development would mitigate existing drainage conditions on  Brawley Road East.  5.3  Correspondence  There was no correspondence.  5.4  Staff Reports  5.4.1 PDP 22-25, Planning and Development (Planning Services)  Department Report  Re: Draft Plan of Subdivision and Zoning By-law Amendment  Applications, Mattamy (Thickson) Limited, File Number: DEV-02-22  (SW-2022-01 and Z-02-22)       3  A question and answer period ensued between Members of  Committee and Staff regarding:   the impact of traffic from the proposed development, the  timeline for intersection improvements at Brawley Road East  and Baldwin Street, and whether there would be any interim  improvements on the Town's portion of Brawley Road East  to Street A; and,   the impact on the proposed development should the Ministry  of Natural Resources deny the removal of Butternut trees,  and whether there was a compensation fund for the removal  of a certain species of trees.  Recommendation:  Moved by Councillor Mulcahy  1. That Council approve the Draft Plan of Subdivision (File  Number: SW-2022-01), subject to the comments included in  Report PDP-22-25 and the Conditions of Draft Plan Approval  included in Attachment #9;  2. That Staff be authorized to prepare a Subdivision  Agreement;  3. That Council approve the amendment to Zoning By-law  #1784, (File Number: Z-02-22) and that a Zoning By-law  Amendment be brought forward for consideration by Council  at a later date;  4. That Williams and Stewart Associates Ltd. be appointed as  the Control Architect for the Draft Plan of Subdivision; and,  5. That the Clerk forward a Notice to those parties and  agencies who requested to be notified of Council's decision.  Carried    5.5  New and Unfinished Business - Planning and Development  There was no new and unfinished business.  6.  General Government  Councillor Lundquist assumed the Chair.       4  6.1  Presentations  There were no presentations.  6.2  Delegations  There were no delegations.  6.3  Correspondence  There was no correspondence.  6.4  Staff Reports  6.4.1 FS 15-25, Financial Services Department Report  Re: 2024 Annual Investment Report  Recommendation:  Moved by Councillor Lundquist  That Report FS 15-25 entitled "2024 Annual Investment Report", be  received for information.  Carried    6.4.2 FS 26-25, Financial Services Department and Community Services  Department Joint Report  Re: Single Source Contract Award for Design Services for the New  Whitby Fire Station   A question and answer period ensued between Members of  Committee and Staff regarding:   whether the cost for the construction of the new Whitby Fire  Station would have an impact on the tax base;   the rationale for the limited tendering and single-source  contract award for the design services for the Whitby Fire  Station;   whether fire stations other than one recently constructed in  Peterborough were reviewed as a comparator for the cost of  the detailed design;   the status of and timeline for the acquisition of land  designated for the West Whitty Fire Station;       5   the utilization of the newly hired firefighters until the new Fire  Station was constructed;   the anticipated improvement in response time for West  Whitby following the design and construction of the new  Whitby Fire Station; and,   whether the growth-related capital projects that would be  deferred to provide funding for the new Fire Station have  been identified.  Recommendation:  Moved by Councillor Cardwell  1. That staff be authorized to award a single source contract to  Thomas Brown Architects for the detailed design of the New  Whitby Fire Station, in the amount of $942,185 plus HST,  funded from capital project # 71231201 - FH6 - New  Construction; and,  2. That a 2025 capital project be approved for the construction  of Fire Hall 6, in the amount of $17,000,000, funded from  internal borrowing between Development Charges reserve  funds as outlined in Report FS 26-25.  Carried    6.4.3 FS 14-25, Financial Services Department Report  Re: Growth-Related Development Fees Exemptions for Affordable  Residential Units  A question and answer period ensued between Members of  Committee and Staff regarding:   details about development charges and interest charges  should a developer exempt from development charges for  the development of affordable residential units change the  development into market rate residential units prior to the  25-year term of the agreement;   whether the Affordable Residential Units Exemption Policy  includes development charge exemptions from both Town  and Regional development charges; and,       6   confirmation that only the developer would be able to  withdraw from the agreement.  Recommendation:  Moved by Councillor Shahid  1. That Council approve the Affordable Residential Units  Exemptions Policy included as Attachment 1 of Report FS  14-25; and,  2. That the Treasurer be delegated the authority to enter into  and make certain amendments to the agreements as  outlined in Report FS 14-25 with the Region of Durham and  property owners for the purpose of providing development  charge, parkland dedication, and community benefit charge  exemptions for Affordable Residential Units.  Carried    6.4.4 CMS 07-25, Community Services Department and Legal and  Enforcement Services Department Joint Report  Re: Proposed Amendment to the Private Transportation Services  By-law, Accessible Taxis  A question and answer period ensued between Members of  Committee and Staff regarding:   whether there was consultation with the Accessibility  Advisory Committee and Durham Region Transit about the  proposed amendment to the Private Transportation Services  By-law; and,   whether other Durham Region municipalities have amended  their by-laws to permit cross-jurisdictional transportation for  licensed accessible taxicabs.  Recommendation:  Moved by Councillor Shahid  1. That Report CMS 07-25 be received for information; and,  2. That the proposed amendments to the Town's Private  Transportation Services By-law # 7398-18, substantially as       7  appended in Attachment 1, be brought to Council for  consideration and adoption.  Carried    6.5  New and Unfinished Business - General Government  There was no new and unfinished business.  7.  Adjournment  Recommendation:  Moved by Councillor Shahid  That the meeting adjourn.  Carried  The meeting adjourned at 7:41 p.m.

New and Unfinished Business    9.1  Regional Review Municipal Responses  A discussion ensued between Members of Council regarding:  • a recent increase in the staffing budget for Councillors in the City  of Toronto due to the reduction in the total number of Councillors;   • the mandate of the Province's Special Advisors;   • the Town's ongoing efforts to find efficiencies and the strategic  direction provided by the Service Delivery Review;   • Whitby's identity and the pride residents have with living in the  Town;   • examining any duplication of services between the Town and the  Region of Durham;   • the importance of local decision making;  • opportunities for shared services between local municipalities and  the Region of Durham;  • how Council and Staff could be involved in promoting the  Province's online consultations about the Regional Review to  residents;  • the Town's recent community survey which indicated that  residents are proud to call Whitby home;  • the efficiency of smaller governments and Councils;  • efficiencies that come from engaged and collaborative staff  members;  • the financial impact of the City of Toronto's amalgamation; and,   • the Town's ongoing efforts to proactively identify best practices  and be competitive with other municipalities.       Resolution # 93-19    Moved By Councillor Roy  Seconded By Councillor Lee    That a motion to introduce a matter pertaining to the Provincial  Government's Regional Government Review be allowed due to its timely  Page 11 of 15  Regular Council Minutes   March 04, 2019 - 7:00 PM    and urgent nature.    Carried on a Two Thirds Vote    Resolution # 94-19    Moved By Councillor Roy  Seconded By Councillor Lee    That in response to the Provincial Government's Regional Government  Review the following resolution, as presented to the Council of the Town  of Whitby be approved:     Whereas, the Government of Ontario has announced a review of  Ontario's eight regional municipalities, the County of Simcoe, and their  lower-tier municipalities by appointed Special Advisors;     Whereas, the provincially appointed advisory body will develop  recommendations for the Minister for the purpose of improving  governance, decision-making and service delivery in the regions and  Simcoe County and their lower-tier municipalities;     Whereas, the Association of Municipalities of Ontario informed its  members that last August, the Minister of Municipal Affairs and Housing  began informal discussions, wishing to hear from people about how this  system of governance is working recognizing it was established in the  1970s;     Whereas, the provincially appointed advisory body has included in the  review consideration of moving to single-tier municipalities or  amalgamating existing municipalities; and,    Whereas, neither the provincial review nor amalgamation was ever  discussed during the recent provincial election by the Premier or our  local Members of Provincial Parliament;     Whereas, 73 percent of residents are satisfied with the customer service  they receive from the Town of Whitby;     Whereas 91 percent of Whitby residents indicate that the quality of life in  Whitby is either good or excellent;     Whereas the Town of Whitby has a history of finding efficiencies and  savings while enhancing programs, services and facilities;    Page 12 of 15  Regular Council Minutes   March 04, 2019 - 7:00 PM      Whereas the Town of Whitby has contributed to Durham Region's AAA  credit rating; and,  Whereas Whitby is recognized as one of Canada's best places to live.     Now Therefore be it Resolved     1. THAT the Council of the Town of Whitby endorses the current  effectiveness of our two-tier municipal government as it has  evolved on mutual agreement with our partner lower-tier  municipalities since its foundation in 1974;  2. THAT the residents of Whitby value their choices, voices and  diversity of representation and residents should have their say  before any change in municipal representation, or possible  merger with other municipalities;  3. THAT Mayors and Councils be provided the opportunity to have  their say before any change to municipal representation is made;  and,  4. THAT this resolution be forwarded to the Special Advisors  appointed by the Province, Durham Region municipalities, the  Association of Municipalities of Ontario, the Minister of Municipal  Affairs and Housing and made publicly available.    Carried on a recorded vote as follows:      For  Against  Abstained  Councillor Alexander  x      Councillor Leahy  x      Councillor Lee  x      Councillor Mulcahy  x      Councillor Newman  x      Councillor Roy  x      Councillor Shahid  x      Councillor Yamada  x      Mayor Mitchell  x        9  0  0  10.
