1    Public Meetings Minutes    February 13, 2023, 7:00 p.m.  Council Chambers  Whitby Town Hall    Present:  Councillor Lee, Chair of Planning and Development  R. Saunders, Commissioner of Planning and Development  F. Santaguida, Commissioner of Legal and Enforcement  Services/Town Solicitor  K. Narraway, Manager of Legislative Services/Deputy Clerk   H. Ellis, Council and Committee Coordinator  L. MacDougall, Council and Committee Coordinator (Recording  Secretary)  _____________________________________________________________________    1.  Public Meetings - 7:00 p.m.     K. Narraway, Manager of Legislative Services/Deputy Clerk, advised that the  Public Meetings are being held in a hybrid meeting format with members of the  public attending both in-person and virtually. Mr. Narraway stated that Members  of Council would receive a written record of all submissions upon publication of  the minutes of the Public Meetings. Mr. Narraway provided an overview of the  format of the public meetings. He advised that members of the public who wish to  be notified of the next report related to any of the public meetings or who wish to  be placed on an Interested Parties List for a matter should email the Town's  Planning and Development Department at planning@whitby.ca or call  905.430.4306.  1.  PDP 03-23, Planning and Development (Planning Services) Department  Report  Re: Zoning By-law Amendment Application, Inuka Developer Inc., 1  Ferguson Avenue, File Number: DEV-25-22, (Z-17-22)   Lauren Taylor, Planner II, provided a PowerPoint Presentation which  included an overview of the application.       2  Dave Meredith, representing Inuka Developer Inc., provided a verbal  presentation which included a detailed overview of the application.  The Chair indicated that comments would now be received by members of  the public.  Brenda Balment, Resident, stated that she was speaking on behalf of  Mainstreet Brooklin Neighbourhood Association (MBNA). She advised that  her understanding of the need for the MBNA to incorporate was a  requirement by the Town based on the MBNA's legal relationship with the  Condominium Corporation due to the sharing of specific services and  assets of the condominium site for which a monthly service fee was paid.  Ms. Balment advised that the MBNA consists of 25 free hold units that  back onto Heber Down Crescent with frontage on Harvey Johnston Way.  She stated that the free hold units were located adjacent to the two  condominium buildings backing onto Winchester Road and the proposed  development. Ms. Balment stated that the Region and the Town have  identified the subject property as an intensification area. She cited her  understanding of an 'intensification area' and inquired whether any  consideration was given to the preservation of the MBNA's village. Ms.  Balment stated that the style of the buildings in the proposed development  would not complement the existing housing in the neighbourhood. She  indicated that there was not any need to include commercial/retail on the  site right in the middle of a residential neighbourhood, noting that when  the traffic lights were installed at Winchester Road and Ferguson Avenue  and the development on the south side of Winchester Road was complete  that there would be access to plenty of commercial and retail  opportunities. Ms. Balment inquired whether the proposed development  was considered high density. She raised concerns where vehicles would  park, noting that the proposed development already has a deficiency of 5  surface parking spaces, that there would only be 1.25 parking spaces for  each of the 60 residential units, and that most residential unit dwellings  would have two vehicles. Ms. Balment raised safety concerns with respect  to emergency vehicle access into and out of the proposed development  given that there was one entry/exit. She raised concerns about parking  and increased traffic on Heber Down Crescent that would result from the  proposed residential and commercial/retail units. Ms. Balment raised  further concerns about the use of Harvey Johnston Way as a short cut  through the existing community, noting that Harvey Johnston Way was a  private road and that the residents in the existing development were  responsible for all maintenance and repairs. Ms. Balment cited an excerpt       3  from By-law # 1784 regarding the erection of any building or structure on a  lot that fronts onto an improved public street, noting that there have not  been any improvements to Heber Down Crescent for 12 years. She  advised that the current proposed plan indicates that there would be eight  semi-detached dwellings fronting onto Heber Down Crescent, noting that  the reversal of the semi-detached dwellings to back onto Heber Down  Crescent would make them aesthetically pleasing and more consistent  with the existing townhouses on Harvey Johnston Way. Ms. Balment  raised concerns about increased noise and emission levels due to the  proposed development, and about residents from the proposed  development encroaching on private property to use the parkette and  playground due to the only open space in the proposed development  being located on roof-tops. Ms. Balment recommended that Heber Down  Crescent be designated as no street parking, and that a clause related to  no encroachment on Harvey Johnston Way be incorporated into the  purchase agreements for the condominiums and semi-detached units.  She noted that clause would mean that vehicle traffic would not be  allowed to cut through the development to avoid traffic on Heber Down  Crescent, that there would not be any access to the open space  playground, and that there would not be any use of the parking spaces in  the MBNA's existing development.  Dean Holtby, Resident, stated that he lives directly across from the  proposed development and that the 8 semi-detached dwellings and the  driveway exiting the complex would be facing his property.  Mr. Holtby  stated that the plan indicated that there would be 16 parking spaces  between the driveways and garages, noting that the size of the garages  were approximately 10 feet long by 20 feet wide. He advised that the  semi-detached dwellings would be 3 storeys in height and would likely  attract younger residents who would likely have 2 vehicles per residence.   Mr. Holtby stated that the garages were so small that there probably would  not be enough room for a vehicle, resulting in vehicles parked on Heber  Down Crescent directly in front of his property.  Marie Richardson, Resident, stated that residents have not been informed  about traffic control at the Winchester Road and Ferguson Avenue  intersection. She suggested that the developer remove all commercial  space from the proposed plan due to increased traffic concerns. Ms.  Richardson stated that westbound on Winchester Road is a right turning  lane for Ferguson Avenue and suggested that the developer consider  right-in/right-out access onto Winchester Road. She further stated that the       4  proposed eight semi-detached dwellings should have internal driveways  rather than driveways onto Heber Down Crescent. Ms. Richardson  suggested that the developer to consider a three-storey condo building to  stay in keeping with the condos on the adjoining property to the east.  Andy Barrington, Resident, provided a Power Point presentation.  Highlights of the presentation included:   concerns about the commercial component of the proposed  development resulting in increased traffic volume well beyond that  of the residential component;   safety concerns for pedestrians and cyclists;   concerns about reduced sightlines for vehicles entering onto  Winchester Road due to the residential/commercial building;   an increase in the volume of speeding vehicles making right turns  from Ferguson Street to Heber Down due to the shallow angle of  the intersection;   an excerpt from the 2016 Ferguson Avenue Class Environmental  Assessment Study which presented an option to close Ferguson  Avenue just south of Heber Down Crescent;   the suggestion of a modified version of Option 7 from the 2016  study which would, provide land for other possible uses including a  park, parking, greenspace, and housing, solve traffic issues and  improve road safety on Ferguson Avenue and Heber Down  Crescent, and eliminate the impact of future traffic volume in the  entire Meadowcrest neighbourhood from the commercial district  currently under construction south of Winchester Road/Highway 7.  Dave Meredith and Staff answered questions regarding:   traffic infiltration into the surrounding neighbourhood and on-street  parking;   the sidewalk location on the south side of Heber Down Crescent;   the number of parking spaces within the proposed development;   issues pertaining to internalizing the driveways;   the intersection at Highway 7/Ferguson Avenue and access to the  Winash Development; and,       5   options for the intersection at this location.  There were no further submissions from the public.  2.  PDP 05-23, Planning and Development (Planning Services) Department  Report  Re: Zoning By-law Amendment Application, 1351789 Ontario Limited,  1621 McEwen Drive, File Number: DEV-01-23 (Z-01-23)  Matthew Wianecki, Planner II, provided a PowerPoint presentation which  included an overview of the application.  Paul Demczak, representing 1351789 Ontario Limited, provided a  PowerPoint presentation which included a detailed overview of the  application.  There were no submissions from the public.  3.  PDP 06-23, Planning and Development (Planning Services) Department  Report  Re: Official Plan Amendment and Zoning By-law Amendment  Applications, 2738183 Ontario Inc., 3 Cassels Road East, File Number:  DEV-36-22 (OPA-2022-W/05, Z-23-22)  Dave Johnson, Planner II, provided a PowerPoint presentation which  included an overview of the applications.  Brayden Libawski, representing 2738183 Ontario Inc., provided a  PowerPoint presentation which included a detailed overview of the  applications.  The Chair indicated that comments would now be received by members of  the public.  Rick Sidler, Resident, raised concerns about the impact of the  development on the value of his property and stated that the proposed  building would be located directly in front of his windows. Mr. Sidler raised  concerns regarding the zoning and whether the residential zoning of the  severed lot would impact the mixed-use zoning of his property.  Staff answered questions regarding:   the zoning of the proposed severed lot and surrounding properties;  and,   the heritage status of 3 Cassels Road.       6  David Breen, Resident, requested images of the proposed development  and stated that the fence between the subject land and his property was  not on the property line.  Brayden Libawski answered questions regarding:   renderings of the proposed building; and,   the process for addressing the fence line issue through reviewing  land surveys.  There were no further submissions from the public.  The meeting adjourned at 8:26 p.m.

1    Accessibility Advisory Committee Minutes    May 2, 2023, 7:00 p.m.  Virtual Meeting    Present:  Larry Brual  Anisa Capener  Victoria Formusa  Liam Lacy, Vice-Chair  Adam Lamplugh  Mike Moraites  Michael Richards  Paul Scott, Chair  Marta Swirydowicz  Regrets:  Colleen Haley  Denise Laframboise  Also Present:  Councillor Cardwell, Mayor's Designate  Michele Cotton, Staff Liaison, Accessibility Coordinator  Heather Ellis, Recording Secretary, Council and Committee  Coordinator  _____________________________________________________________________    1.  Call to Order  2.  Appointment of Chair and Vice Chair  The Committee was advised that the appointment for Chair and Vice Chair of the  Accessibility Advisory Committee for the January 1, 2023 to December 31, 2023  term would take place at this time.  Michele Cotton called for the nominations for the position of Chair of the  Accessibility Advisory Committee.  Liam Lacy nominated Paul Scott for the position of Chair of the Accessibility  Advisory Committee.  Paul Scott accepted the nomination.       2  There were no further nominations and the nominations were closed.  Michele Cotton called for nominations for the position of Vice-Chair of the  Accessibility Advisory Committee.  Adam Lamplugh nominated Victoria Formusa for the position of Vice-Chair of the  Accessibility Advisory Committee.  Victoria Formusa accepted the nomination.  Marta Swirydowicz nominated Liam Lacy for the position of Vice-Chair of the  Accessibility Advisory Committee.  Liam Lacy accepted the nomination.  Victoria Formusa withdrew her acceptance for nomination.  There were no further nominations and the nominations were closed.  Recommendation:  Moved by Liam Lacy  That Paul Scott be appointed Chair of the Accessibility Advisory Committee for a  term ending December 31, 2023.  Carried    Recommendation:  Moved by Marta Swirydowicz  That Liam Lacy be appointed Vice-Chair of the Accessibility Advisory Committee  for a term ending December 31, 2023.  Carried    3.  Declarations of Conflict of Interest  There were no declarations of conflict of interest.  4.  Approval of Previous Minutes  Recommendation:  Moved by Liam Lacy  That the Accessibility Advisory Committee minutes of October 4, 2022 be  approved.       3  Carried    5.  General Business and Reports  5.1  Subcommittee Selection  Michele Cotton provided an overview of the Built Environment and Site  Plan Subcommittee, and Customer Service and Communications  Subcommittee and requested volunteers for each subcommittee.  Larry Brual, Adam Lamplugh, Mike Moraites, and Marta Swirydowicz  volunteered for the Built Environment and Site Plan Subcommittee.  Victoria Formusa, Liam Lacy, Mike Moraites, Michael Richards, Paul  Scott, and Marta Swirydowicz volunteered for the Customer Service and  Communications Subcommittee.  5.2  Work Plan and Priorities  Michele Cotton requested feedback from the Committee regarding the  2022-2026 Work Plan and priorities. Ms. Cotton advised that Section 1 of  the Work Plan was legislated by the province, and Section 2 was  legislated by the Planning Act. She stated that the Committee may provide  feedback and set goals under Sections 3 and 4 of the Work Plan. Ms.  Cotton provided an overview of various activities from the 2018-2022  Work Plan including the Community Survey, Accessibility Improvement  Grant for businesses, and Parks and Open Space Audit.  Discussion ensued regarding:   brainstorming action items based on the Community Survey  results;   raising community awareness of the Accessibility Improvement  Grant;   continuing to develop the Parks and Open Space Audit;   standardizing language for discussing accessibility, disability, and  disability groups;   addressing concerns regarding the prioritization of accessibility  over intersectionality;   consolidating ideas for Work Plan priorities into an excel  spreadsheet;       4   the Regional Municipality of Durham 2022-2025 Multi-year  Accessibility Plan review;   addressing concerns regarding pedestrian crossing time limits at  specific intersections; and,   addressing concerns regarding sidewalks within the Town that  require improvements.  6.  Council Update  Councillor Cardwell provided an update regarding:   the Town of Whitby's Community Strategic Plan;   Employment Programs through the Abilities Centre;   an upcoming presentation by Metrolinx to Council;   continuing to plan for a new hospital in Whitby; and,   the goal of Ontario's accessibility legislation of ensuring universal  accessibility in the Province of Ontario by January 1, 2025, including full  compliance of Ontario businesses.  7.  Other Business  7.1  PowerHockey Durham  Michele Cotton advised that PowerHockey Durham was launching this  Spring. Ms. Cotton stated that registration was free and the introductory  program would be held on Saturdays at the Abilities Centre between May  13, 2023 and June 24, 2023 from 11:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. She further  stated that a Demo and Try-It event would be held on Sunday, May 7,  2023 from 2:00 to 3:30 p.m.  8.  Next Meeting  Tuesday, June 6, 2022 - 7:00 p.m.  9.  Adjournment  Recommendation:  Moved by Liam Lacy  That the meeting adjourn.  Carried       5  The meeting adjourned at 8:25 p.m.  Note: These minutes were approved by the Accessibility Advisory  Committee on June 6, 2023.

Whitby Sustainability Advisory Committee Minutes  December 1, 2021 - 7:00 PM  Virtual Meeting           Present:  Beatrice Adesemowo, Chair   Poonam Dewan   Robynne Dunn   Gayle Giesbrecht  Mahroz Hussain  Laurie Kuchirka, Vice-Chair    Patti Mavins, Whitby in Bloom Committee Representative   Michelle Thornley     Also Present:  Councillor Yamada, Mayor's Designate  Jade Schofield, Project Manager, Sustainability and Climate Change  Suprajha Vaithianathan, Staff Liaison, Energy & Sustainability  Programs Coordinator  Heather Ellis, Council and Committee Coordinator (Recording  Secretary)    Regrets:  David Budd  Timothy Eric  Melanie Maloney  Miranda Pautler  Judy Rivers       Call to Order   1.  Disclosures of Interest    1.1  There were no disclosures of interest.    2.  Approval of Previous Minutes    2.1  Minutes - November 3, 2021      Recommendation:    Moved By Michelle Thornley     Whitby Sustainability Advisory Committee Minutes   December 01, 2021 - 7:00 PM    That the Whitby Sustainability Advisory Committee minutes of  November 3, 2021 be approved.    Carried  3.  Presentations    3.1  Lisamaria Akeson, Waste Management Analyst, Town of Whitby  Re: Rethink Your Waste  Lisamaria Akeson provided a presentation regarding Rethink Your  Waste and the Waste Sorting Game. Ms. Akeson stated that  gamification was a marketing strategy used to change peoples'  behaviours. Highlights of the presentation included:  • using promotional and educational tools to ensure waste was  properly sorted in residential homes;  • the promotional and educational tools used by the Town such as  the waste collection calendar, newspaper advertisements, social  media campaigns, online websites, apps, and the waste sorting  game; and,  • using the data collected by the waste sorting game to create  targeted waste management campaigns.  A brief question and answer period ensued regarding:  • whether the Town would continue using the app;  • how to engage more students; and,  • whether the waste sorting game could be used by schools to earn  points and redeem them for tangible items such as sporting  equipment.      3.2  Jade Schofield, Project Manager, Sustainability and Climate Change,  Town of Whitby  Re: Climate Change Adaptation Plan  Jade Schofield provided a presentation regarding the Climate Change  Adaptation Plan. Highlights of the presentation included:  • a timeline of Whitby's climate actions;  • defining corporate actions and community based actions;   • the Race to Resilience and Race to Zero campaigns;  • Phase 1 of the Climate Change Adaptation Plan, Climate  Adaptation which includes a strategy to mitigate and avoid risks  caused by climate change;  • modelling methods to identify the risks of increased temperature,  precipitation, and wilder weather, and assessing vulnerability to  assets such as flood damage to property;  Page 2 of 6  Whitby Sustainability Advisory Committee Minutes   December 01, 2021 - 7:00 PM    • community engagement approaches including individual story  telling through the ISeeChange App and traditional methods  including surveys, and webinars; and,  • incentives to encourage the public to use the ISeeChange App.  A question and answer period ensued regarding:  • the capacity for electric fleets and electrification of corporate  buildings;  • whether the Town had considered using district heating;  • details of the geo-thermal model for the Whitby Sports Complex;  and,  • strategies used to engage developers in the Net Zero  Homes/Carbon Standards.     4.  Delegations    4.1  There were no delegations.    5.  General Business and Reports    5.1  Electric Vehicle Charging Stations User Policy and Traffic By-law  Amendment  Jade Schofield advised that the Electric Vehicle Charging Stations User  Policy and Traffic By-law Amendment Report would be presented to the  Committee of the Whole on December 6, 2021. Ms. Schofield stated  that the fees associated with the electric vehicle charging stations were  approved by Council on November 29, 2021. She further stated that a  service charge would be charged and placed into a fund for future  sustainable initiatives.  A brief question and answer period ensued regarding whether electric  vehicle charging stations could be pre-booked.      5.2  Zero Carbon Whitby Costing Study Pre-Budget Approval  Jade Schofield advised that the Zero Carbon Whitby Costing Study Pre- Budget Approval Report would be presented to the Committee of the  Whole on December 6, 2021. Ms. Schofield stated that the Report  inlcuded a recommendation that Council authorize staff to extend the  existing Zero Carbon Whitby Contract and retain Sustainable Solutions  Group to complete the Zero Carbon Whitby Costing Study.      5.3  Whitby Climate Change Master Plan  Page 3 of 6  Whitby Sustainability Advisory Committee Minutes   December 01, 2021 - 7:00 PM    Jade Schofield advised that the Whitby Climate Change Master Plan  Report would be presented to the Committee of the Whole on December  6, 2021. Ms. Schofield stated that the Report included the key  deliverables of Phase 2 of the Climate Change Mitigation Plan and the  importance of addressing greenhouse gas emissions.      5.4  Inclusion, Diversity, Equity, and Anti-Racisim (IDEA) Project Update  Suprajha Vaithianathan stated that the Inclusion, Diversity, Equity, and  Anti-Racism (IDEA) Project was seeking community feedback. Ms.  Vaithianathan advised that there would be a Virtual Community Open  House on December 2, 2021 from 6:00 p.m. to 7:30 p.m. for further  information regarding the Project.       5.5  First Quarter Whitby Sustainability Advisory Committee Activities  Suprajha Vaithianathan requested feedback from the Committee  regarding additional events or topics the Committee would like to add to  the Committee's 2022 activities.  Discussion ensued regarding:  • hosting a community event to remove invasive species; and,  • an educational session or campaign regarding the ban on single  use plastics.      5.6  Second Quarter Whitby Sustainability Advisory Committee Activities  Suprajha Vaithianathan requested feedback and suggestions from the  Committee regarding activities for Pollinator Week.  Discussion ensued regarding:  • promoting native bee species;  • hosting an activity for making solitary bee homes;  • offering a native plant sale; and,  • reaching out to Indigenous knowledge keepers.      5.7  Whitby in Bloom Committee Update  Patti Mavins provided an update regarding the Whitby in Bloom  Committee which included:  • continuing to search for additional locations for the 2022 Whitby  in Bloom Garden Tour;  • the results from the Preparing Your Garden for Winter Webinar;  Page 4 of 6  Whitby Sustainability Advisory Committee Minutes   December 01, 2021 - 7:00 PM    • planning the 2022 Whitby in Bloom Committee Webinar Series;  and,  • the King Street Cooperative Community Garden.    6.  Correspondence    6.1  There was no correspondence.    7.  Council Update    7.1  Councillor Yamada provided an update regarding:  • a desire to increase density around major transit stations to  encourage use of public transit;  • Council's endorsement of the 2022 Dates of Significance for  Proclamations submitted by the Whitby Diversity and Inclusion  Advisory Committee;  • naming the unnamed West Whitby Park the Des Newman Whit- Bee District Park;  • hiring a Temporary Capital Projects Supervisor for the Whitby  Sports Complex;  • the signalization of regional intersections and the Hydro Electric  Power Corridor Trail Crossings; and,  • the 2022 to 2026 Economic Development Strategy.    8.  Other Business    8.1  There was no other business.    9.  Next Meeting    9.1  Wednesday, January 5, 2022 - 7:00 p.m.  Virtual Meeting    10.  Adjournment    10.1 Motion to Adjourn      Recommendation:    Moved By Laurie Kuchirka    That the meeting adjourn.    Carried  Page 5 of 6  Whitby Sustainability Advisory Committee Minutes   December 01, 2021 - 7:00 PM      The meeting adjourned at 8:58 p.m.       Note: These minutes were approved by the Whitby Sustainability Advisory  Committee on February 2, 2022. Animal Services Appeal Committee Minutes  January 22, 2020 – 3:00 PM  Committee Room One  Whitby Town Hall       Present:  C. Blissett, Chair  J. Herzog-Evans, Member  K. Langille, Member  W. Nunn, Member  S. O'Dwyer, Member     Also Present:  A. Gratton, Staff Liaison, Manager of Enforcement Services   J. Bartlett, Animal Services Officer  H. Oerlemans, Council & Committee Coordinator (Recording  Secretary)    Regrets:  None noted    1.  Call to Order    1.1  The meeting was called to order at 3:03 p.m.    2.  Appointment of Chair    2.1  The Committee was advised that the appointment for the Chair of the  Animal Services Appeal Committee for the January 1, 2020 to  December 31, 2020 term would take place at this time.  Andre Gratton called for nominations for the position of Chair of the  Animal Services Appeal Committee.  Jasmine Herzog-Evans nominated Carleen Blissett for the position of  Chair.  Carleen Blissett accepted the nomination.  There were no further nominations and the nominations were closed.      Recommendation:    Moved By Jasmine Herzog-Evans    That Carleen Blissett be appointed Chair of the Animal Services Appeal   Animal Services Appeal Committee Minutes   January 22, 2020 - 3:00 PM    Committee for a term ending December 31, 2020.    Carried    Carleen Blissett assumed the Chair.  3.  Disclosures of Interest    3.1  There were no disclosures of interest.  A. Gratton, Manager of Enforcement Services, addressed the appellants  and introduced the Committee. Mr. Gratton outlined the authority of the  Animal Services Appeal Committee and explained that the Committee  has the ability to confirm Orders to Restrain, modify or rescind them.    4.  Appeal Hearing    4.1  Appeal of Order to Restrain a Dog  1505 Dufferin Street, Whitby ON  Appeal # ASA 20-01  J. Bartlett, Animal Services Officer, appeared before the Committee and  provided an overview of the circumstances that led him to issue the  Order. Mr. Bartlett stated that the victim had sustained a bite wound on  his left calf. He advised that the dog had a history of biting and was in  foster care.  A question and answer period ensued between J. Bartlett and the  Committee regarding the incident including:  • what evidence supported the victim's statement; and,  • whether the bite required stitches.  L. Templeton, the appellant, appeared before the Committee and  provided a history of the dog. Ms. Templeton advised that measures had  been taken to ensure that the dog remained on a leash when outside of  the home. The appellant requested that the muzzle condition be lifted  from the Order.  A question and answer period ensued between the appellant and the  Committee regarding the size and age of the dog.  B. McNutt, Standard Poodles in Need, Rescue & Rehome, provided  information regarding the history of the dog while in foster care and the  dog's temperment. Ms. McNutt advised that since the incident, the dog  was receiving medication for anxiety and working with a professional  dog trainer.  Page 2 of 6  Animal Services Appeal Committee Minutes   January 22, 2020 - 3:00 PM    The Committee excused the appellant, B. McNutt, A. Gratton and J.  Bartlett from the room at 3:27 p.m. and reviewed the matter. The  appellant, B. McNutt, A. Gratton and J. Bartlett returned to the meeting  at 3:34 p.m.      Recommendation:    Moved By S. O'Dwyer    That the Order to Restrain a Dog for the dog residing at 1505 Dufferin  Street, be confirmed.    Carried    4.2  Appeal of Order to Restrain a Dog  129 Halls Road North, Whitby ON  Appeal # ASA 20-02  J. Bartlett, Animal Services Officer, appeared before the Committee and  provided an overview of the circumstances that led him to issue the  Order. Mr. Bartlett stated that a neighbour's dog had been injured during  the incident.  A question and answer period ensued between the Committee and J.  Bartlett regarding the size of the neighbour's dog and the age of the  neighbour in control of the dog at the time of the incident.  S. Foston, the appellant, appeared before the Committee and advised  that the incident occurred on his property and that the neighbour's dog  entered onto his front yard. Mr. Foston further advised that the  neighbour's dog was not properly controlled as he was on a retractable  leash that was extended beyond the 2 metre leash length requirement  contained in the Town's Responsible Pet Ownership By-law. Mr. Foston  stated that his dog approached the neighbour's dog when the  neighbour's dog came onto his property and that the neighbour's dog  had a history of aggression.  Mr. Foston requested that the Committee remove the conditions to  muzzle and prohibition from attending any off-leash dog park in the  Town of Whitby. He provided a history of his dog which included:  • no acts of aggression;  • no previous altrications with another dog or person; and,  • training and use as a duck retriever.  Mr. Foston advised that he has fully fenced his property and taken  Page 3 of 6  Animal Services Appeal Committee Minutes   January 22, 2020 - 3:00 PM    measures to ensure that his dog is not able to leave the property.  A question and answer period ensued between the appellant and the  Committee regarding details of the event, specifically the location of the  incident and provocation.  The Committee excused the appellant, A. Gratton and J. Bartlett from  the room at 3:56 p.m. and reviewed the matter. The appellant, A.  Gratton and J. Bartlett returned to the meeting at 4:02 p.m.      Recommendation:    Moved By J. Herzog-Evans    That the Order to Restrain a Dog for the dog residing at 129 Halls Road  North, be modified to remove conditions 2 and 4.    Carried    4.3  Appeal of Order to Restrain a Dog  61 Seaboard Gate, Whitby ON  Appeal # ASA 20-03  J. Bartlett, Animal Services Officer, appeared before the Committee and  provided an overview of the circumstances that led him to issue the  Order. Mr. Bartlett stated that during the incident, a young girl was  injured on her thigh.  A question and answer period ensued between J. Bartlett and the  Committee regarding:  • who identified the dog; and,  • how far from the owner's property the incident happened.  J. Mitchell and A. Oddi, the appellants, appeared before the Committee  to request that the condition to muzzle be removed from the Order.  J. Mitchell stated that the dog was off-leash and with her at the time of  the incident; however, she did not witness an incident involving her dog.  Ms. Mitchell only became aware that an incident with a young girl and a  dog occurred when a neighbour came to her home to advise her that her  dog bit a young girl. Ms. Mitchell further stated that the dog had no  history of aggression or previous incidents with a person or another dog.  She advised that the area where the incident occurred was known for  having off-leash dogs and that there were other chocolate labs and large  brown dogs in the neighbourhood who visited the park.  Page 4 of 6  Animal Services Appeal Committee Minutes   January 22, 2020 - 3:00 PM    A question and answer period ensued between the appellant and the  Committee regarding;  • where the appellant was at the time of the incident;  • where the appellant's dogs were at the time of the incident;  • whether the appellant witnessed any incident between two young  girls and a dog; and,  • how the dog was identified as being involved in the incident.  K. Vinson, Animal Behaviour Consultant for the appellant, stated that the  dog's score on the Cornell Aggression Screen was zero which indicated  that the dog exhibited no aggression on any of the criteria of the  aggression screen.  A question and answer period ensued between K. Vinson and the  Committee regarding what the general distribution in scoring and what  the average score was for dogs on the Cornell Aggression Screen.  The Committee excused the appellants, K. Vinson, A. Gratton and J.  Bartlett from the room at 5:09 p.m. and reviewed the matter. The  appellants, K. Vinson, A. Gratton and J. Bartlett returned to the meeting  at 5:20 p.m.      Recommendation:    Moved By W. Nunn    That the Order to Restrain a Dog for the dog residing at 61 Seaboard  Gate, be modified to remove conditions 2 and 4.    Carried  4.  Adjournment    4.1  Motion to Adjourn      Recommendation:    Moved By K. Langille    That the meeting adjourn.    Carried    The meeting adjourned at 5:23 p.m.  Page 5 of 6  Animal Services Appeal Committee Minutes   January 22, 2020 - 3:00 PM      H. Oerlemans, Council and Committee  Coordinator      Page 6 of 6

filename: Ethno Cultural and Diversity Advisory Committee-06 Jun 2019.pdf
category: Ethno Cultural and Diversity Advisory Committee
text: Ethno-cultural and Diversity Advisory Committee Minutes  June 6, 2019 – 7:15 PM  Committee Room One  Whitby Town Hall    Present:  Mayline Brown, Chair  Cheryl Frayne  Brianna Nelson  Catherine Philogene  Vivek Singh  Ayse Yuksel     Also Present:  Councillor Shahid, Mayor's Designate   Sarah Hickman, Durham Region Representative, Policy Advisor,  Diversity & Immigration Program  Mallory Dawson, Whitby Public Library Representative   Kim Evans, Staff Liaison, Supervisor, Seniors' Services  Heather Oerlemans, Council and Committee Coordinator  (Recording Secretary)    Regrets:  Andrea Cecchetto, Vice-Chair    1.  Disclosures of Interest    1.1  There were no disclosures of interest.    2.  Approval of Previous Minutes    2.1  Minutes - April 4, 2019      Recommendation:    Moved By Catherine Philogene    That the Ethno-cultural and Diversity Advisory Committee minutes of  April 4, 2019 be approved.    Carried  3.  Presentations    3.1  Sarah Hickman, Policy Advisor, Region of Durham   Ethno-cultural and Diversity Advisory Committee Minutes   June 06, 2019 - 7:15 PM    Re: Whitby Census Information  Sarah Hickman, Policy Advisor, Region of Durham, appeared before the  Committee and provided information regarding the Whitby Census  which included:   • the number of people per household, the average age of  residents, and the percentage of seniors;  • household income demographics;  • the percentage of people living in poverty based on the provincial  low income cut-off;  • the percentage of immigrants into the Region of Durham;  • the top ten new immigrant origin countries;  • the importance of immigrants to fill labour needs and skill  shortages; and,  • the demographics for mode of transportation and length of  commute.  Sarah Hickman advised that the Local Diversity and Immigration  Partnership Council was developing a new working group called the  Immigrant Advisory Working Group. She further advised that questions  regarding the Local Diversity and Immigration Partnership Council  should be directed to ldipc@durham.ca.    4.  Delegations    4.1  There were no delegations.    5.  General Business and Reports    5.1  Committee Name Change  Kim Evans advised that the Committee had expressed concerns  regarding the Committee's name and agreed that Ethno-cultural and  Diversity Advisory Committee did not reflect the entire mandate of the  Committee and that it was misleading to the public. She further advised  that the Committee had decided to change the name of the Ethno- cultural and Diversity Advisory Committee to the Whitby Diversity and  Inclusion Advisory Committee.      Recommendation:    Moved By Ayse Yuksel    That the Ethno-cultural and Diversity Advisory Committee requests that  Council endorse changing the Committee's name to the Whitby Diversity  Page 2 of 5  Ethno-cultural and Diversity Advisory Committee Minutes   June 06, 2019 - 7:15 PM    and Inclusion Advisory Committee.    Carried    5.2  Upcoming Events  Youth Pride Day - June 8, 2019  Kim Evans advised that Brianna Nelson would be in attendance at the  Committee's Youth Pride Day booth at the Durham District School  Board. A brief discussion ensued regarding the materials that would be  required for the booth.  Canada Day - July 1, 2019 - Morning  Kim Evans advised that volunteers would be required to host a  Citizenship Ceremony at the Centennial Building on Canada Day.   Canada Day - July 1, 2019 - Afternoon  Kim Evans advised that volunteers would be required for an interactive   'Showcase of Cultures' booth at the Canada Day event. A brief  discussion ensued and it was decided that, due to the lack of volunteers,  the Committee would not participate in this event.  Movies in the Park  Councillor Shahid requested that the Committee consider foreign movie  titles for Movies in the Park. She stated that movie selections should  reflect cultural diversity.  Culture in the Square - July 16 and August 13, 2019  Kim Evans provided information regarding the Culture in the Square,  World of Dance event and requested Members volunteer to participate  in the event. She further requested volunteers for the Culture in the  Square, Indigenous Traditions event and advised that the theme would  be "Water is Life".   Harvest Festival - September 14, 2019  Kim Evans advised that volunteers were required for the Ethno-cultural  and Diversity Advisory Committee booth at the Harvest Festival.   School Presentation - Fall 2019  Cheryl Frayne advised that she was waiting for a response from Julie  Payette Public School regarding the presentation.      Page 3 of 5  Ethno-cultural and Diversity Advisory Committee Minutes   June 06, 2019 - 7:15 PM    Recommendation:    Moved By Cheryl Frayne    That the Ethno-cultural and Diversity Advisory Committee recommends  that the Town of Whitby compose an Indigenous Land  Acknowledgement Statement and that all events are preceded by  reading the Indigenous Land Acknowledgement Statement.    Carried    5.3  Ethno-cultural and Diversity Advisory Committee Educational Items  Kim Evans requested ideas from the Committee for giveaways such as  T-shirts, pens, and name tags.      5.4  Proclamations for September  Kim Evans advised that the Committee's proclamations for National  Indigenous Peoples Day and Canadian Multiculturalism Day were  endorsed by Council at its meeting held on May 27, 2019.    6.  Correspondence    6.1  There was no correspondence.    7.  Council Update    7.1  Councillor Shahid provided updates regarding:  • installing a rainbow crosswalk or other rainbow themed  opportunities in Whitby;  • the Parking Master Plan; and,  • the Cultural Survey.  Councillor Shahid encouraged the Committee to comment on the  Parking Master Plan and complete the Cultural Survey.    8.  Other Business    8.1  Indigenous Themed Sports Logos  Kim Evans advised that the Town was consulting with other  municipalities regarding a policy for Indigenous themed sports logos.      8.2  Rainbow Crosswalk  Page 4 of 5  Ethno-cultural and Diversity Advisory Committee Minutes   June 06, 2019 - 7:15 PM    Kim Evans advised that rainbow crosswalks were being investigated by  Town Staff and that the Region of Durham had installed a rainbow  crosswalk at the Rossland Road entrance to the Regional Headquarters  parking lot.    9.  Next Meeting    9.1  September 5, 2019 - 7:15 p.m.  Boardroom, Whitby Seniors' Activity Centre  801 Brock Street South    10.  Adjournment    10.1 Motion to Adjourn      Recommendation:    Moved By Cheryl Frayne    That the meeting adjourn.    Carried    The meeting adjourned at 8:46 p.m.    H. Oerlemans, Council and Committee  Coordinator  M. Brown, Committee Chair    Page 5 of 5

Committee of the Whole Minutes  January 27, 2020 - 7:00 PM  Council Chambers  Whitby Town Hall              Present:  Mayor Mitchell  Councillor Leahy  Councillor Lee  Councillor Mulcahy  Councillor Newman  Councillor Roy  Councillor Shahid  Councillor Yamada    Also Present:  M. Gaskell, Chief Administrative Officer  J. Kittle, Director of Operational Services  W. Mar, Commissioner of Legal and Enforcement Services/Town  Solicitor  K. Nix, Commissioner of Corporate Services/Treasurer  J. Romano, Commissioner of Community Services  H. Ellis, Executive Advisor to the Mayor  S. Klein, Director of Strategic Initiatives  C. Harris, Town Clerk   L. MacDougall, Council and Committee Coordinator (Recording  Secretary)    Regrets:  Councillor Alexander    Call to Order  Call of the Roll: The Clerk  Declarations of Pecuniary Interest      Mayor Mitchell declared a pecuniary interest under the Municipal  Conflict of Interest Act regarding Item 4.1, Report, CAO 01-20,  Employment Land Investment Readiness Assessment – Update, as  Mayor Mitchell and his family have an interest in 5455 Ashburn Road  which has been identified in the report as an area to be serviced.  Mayor  Mitchell left the meeting during the discussion and voting of this matter.    Page 1 of 9  Committee of the Whole Minutes   January 27, 2020 - 7:00 PM      General Government     Councillor Leahy assumed the Chair.  1.  Presentations    1.1  There were no presentations.    2.  Delegations    2.1  There were no delegations.    3.  Correspondence    3.1  There was no correspondence.    4.  Staff Reports    4.1  Office of the Chief Administrative Officer Report, CAO 01-20  Re: Employment Land Investment Readiness Assessment – Update  Having previously declared a conflict of interest, Mayor Mitchell left the  meeting and did not take part in the discussion or vote on the matter.   A question and answer period ensued between Members of Council and  Staff regarding:  • the development of employments lands being one of the Town's  highest priorities to generate business growth and local  employment in order to balance the residential growth;  • a presentation by Town Staff in 2020 to provide an update;  • establishing a strategy for employment lands within the Economic  Development Strategy;  • feedback obtained from the Provincial Government with respect  to the status of the release and servicing of provincially owned  lands along Highway 407 and 412 corridors;  • the response from Open for Business Ontario with respect to  generating revenue and declaring surplus properties, and  whether it would be reinforced as part of future budget  consultations;  • whether the Region of Durham servicing employment lands  would have an impact on the Province to declare surplus land;  • the challenges associated with serviced employment land not  available for development, and incentives to motivate landowners  to invest in developing on these lands;  Page 2 of 9  Committee of the Whole Minutes   January 27, 2020 - 7:00 PM    • opportunities through the Town, the Region or the Province to  recover funds associated with servicing employment land through  front-ending agreements and sharing those costs with  landowners who subsequently benefit; and,  • whether the Province has released employment lands in the past  in Whitby or another municipality, and whether those lands were  developed.      Recommendation:    Moved By Councillor Roy    1. That Report CAO 01-20 be received as information regarding an  update to the employment land investment readiness  assessment; and,  2. That the Clerk forward a copy of Staff Report CAO 01-20 to the  Region of Durham Planning and Economic Development,  Finance and Public Works Departments and to the Ministry of  Transportation.    Carried later in the meeting (see following motion)    Recommendation:    Moved By Councillor Newman    That the main motion be amended by including Item 2 as follows, and  the recommendation renumbered accordingly:  2. That given the imperative need for greater local business, that Staff  include a strategy for the development of employment lands in the  Economic Development Strategy to be presented to Council in 2020.    Carried    The main motion, as amended, was then carried as follows:    Recommendation:    Moved By Councillor Newman    1. That Report CAO 01-20 be received as information regarding an  update to the employment land investment readiness  assessment;  Page 3 of 9  Committee of the Whole Minutes   January 27, 2020 - 7:00 PM    2. That given the imperative need for greater local business, that  Staff include a strategy for the development of employment lands  in the Economic Development Strategy to be presented to  Council in 2020; and,  3. That the Clerk forward a copy of Staff Report CAO 01-20 to the  Region of Durham Planning and Economic Development,  Finance and Public Works Departments and to the Ministry of  Transportation.    Carried    Mayor Mitchell returned to the meeting at 7:19 p.m.    4.2  Office of the Chief Administrative Officer Report, CAO 02-20  Re: Community Development Funds – 2019 Annual Report  A question and answer period ensued between Members of Council and  Staff regarding:  • whether the balance of the Mayor's Community Development  Fund and the Performing Arts Development Fund from 2019  would carry over into 2020; and,  • whether groups or organizations could peruse a grant associated  with the Culture Plan once it was implemented.      Recommendation:    Moved By Councillor Newman    That Report CAO 02-20 regarding the 2019 Annual Report for the  Mayor's Community Development Fund and the Performing Arts  Community Development Fund be received.     Carried    4.3  Corporate Services Department Report, CS 04-20  Re: Temporary Borrowing By-law       Recommendation:    Moved By Councillor Yamada    That a By-law be brought forward to authorize the temporary borrowing  of an amount up to Fifteen Million dollars for cash flow purposes, if  Page 4 of 9  Committee of the Whole Minutes   January 27, 2020 - 7:00 PM    required, at any one time during the calendar year 2020.     Carried    4.4  Legal and Enforcement Services Department Report, LS 01-20  Re: Proposed Amendments to the Private Transportation Services By- law  A question and answer period ensued between Members of Council and  Staff regarding:  • inconsistencies in the private transportation services by-laws  among municipalities in the Region of Durham; and,  • whether it would be appropriate for the Region to set standards  for all municipalities in the Region to ensure consistency in the  issuance of taxi and private transportation licences across the  Region.      Recommendation:    Moved By Councillor Roy    That staff be directed to bring forward a by-law to amend the Private  Transportation Services By-law to give effect to the recommendations  contained in Report LS 01-20.    Carried    4.5  Public Works Department Report, PW 01-20  Re: Fees for Services and Activities Provided and Performed by the  Town of Whitby Public Works Department      Recommendation:    Moved By Councillor Mulcahy    1. That Council approve the proposed Fees for Services and  Activities provided and performed by the Public Works  Department as outlined within Public Works Report PW 01-20;  and,  2. That the Town Clerk be directed to bring forward a by-law to  amend the Fees and Charges By-law to give effect to the  recommendations contained in Report PW 01-20.    Page 5 of 9  Committee of the Whole Minutes   January 27, 2020 - 7:00 PM    Carried  5.  New and Unfinished Business - General Government    5.1  Region of Durham Community Improvement Plan - Affordable Housing  Councillor Newman introduced a motion regarding the Region of  Durham Community Improvement Plan - Affordable Housing.  Discussion ensued between Members of Council regarding:  • the need and the requirement for affordable housing in Whitby;  • the funds required to support the need of affordable housing in  Durham Region, and the lack of financial support from all levels  of government;  • the definition of affordable housing including rent-geared-to- income, seniors, new home buyers, downsizing and social  assistance;  • the percentage of a household income consumed by rent or  mortgage;  • the possibility of a representative from Durham Region providing  an update to Council on the implementation of the  recommendations from the Affordable Housing Task Force;  • the financial role of the Region versus the Town with respect to  affordable housing; and,  • the provision of a link on the Town's Website to Durham Region's  Website for information on affordable housing, and the difficulty in  identifying affordable housing in Whitby on the Town's website or  the Region's website.      Recommendation:    Moved By Councillor Newman    Whereas the Council of the Region of Durham adopted  recommendations on December 18, 2019 with respect to Report #2019- COW-35 in support of retaining consulting services for a comprehensive  review for the design of a proposed Regional Community Improvement  Plan for the Region of Durham;     Now Therefore be it Resolved:     1. That the Council of the Town of Whitby endorses this initiative of  the Region of Durham and supports Staff of the Town of Whitby  in providing support as required to ensure policies and relief  mechanisms are fully considered through the consultation  Page 6 of 9  Committee of the Whole Minutes   January 27, 2020 - 7:00 PM    process to promote the development of affordable housing in the  Town of Whitby of the Region of Durham; and,   2. That the Clerk be directed to forward a copy of this resolution to  the Region of Durham and Durham Area Municipalities for  information.    The disposition of this matter, Item 5.1, was determined by the  motion to table below.    Recommendation:    Moved By Councillor Roy    That the motion regarding the Region of Durham Community  Improvement Plan - Affordable Housing be tabled.    Carried    5.2  Installation of a Crosswalk or a Crossing Guard - Springwood Street and  Nicol Avenue.  Councillor Shahid inquired about the future installation of a crosswalk or  a crossing guard in the area of Springwood Street and Nicol Avenue.  J. Kittle, Director of Operational Services, advised that Transportation  Staff would review the necessity of a crosswalk or crossing guard at this  location in conjunction with other locations of concern.  A brief question and answer period ensued between Members of  Council and Staff regarding the timeline for the review, and whether a  staff report would be presented to Council should there be a number of  locations currently under review.      5.3  Whitby in Bloom Committee Member Leslie Tate  Councillor Shahid advised of the passing of Leslie Tate who was a  Member of the Whitby in Bloom Committee and the Horticultural  Society. Councillor Shahid expressed condolences to Ms. Tate's family.      5.4  Coronavirus   Councillor Mulcahy inquired regarding the Town's preparedness with  respect to the Coronavirus and whether there was a protocol in place for  this type of situation.  Page 7 of 9  Committee of the Whole Minutes   January 27, 2020 - 7:00 PM    M. Gaskell, Chief Administrative Officer advised that the situation would  be continuously monitored, and that staff would have all necessary  personal protective equipment in order to provide service to the public.       5.5  New and Unfinished Business List - Item MD - 4151  Councilor Yamada inquired about the status of Item MD - 4151  regarding community safety zones.  J. Kittle, Director of Operational Services advised that he would  investigate the matter and advise accordingly.      5.6  New and Unfinished Business List - Item MD - 5045  Councillor Lee inquired about the status of Item MD 5045 regarding  traffic calming on Robert Attersley Drive and Promenade Drive.  J. Kittle, Director of Operational Services advised that a meeting with  stakeholders and residents would take place prior to June 2020, a report  would presented to Council in September 2020, and implementation  would take place by December 2020.       Adjournment      Adjournment      Recommendation:    Moved By Councillor Newman    That the meeting adjourn.    Carried    The meeting adjourned at 7:49 p.m.    Advisory Committee Minutes – For Information Only      • Accessibility Advisory Committee Minutes - January 7, 2020  • Whitby Sustainability Advisory Committee Minutes - January 8,  2020  • Active Transportation and Safe Roads Advisory Committee  Page 8 of 9  Committee of the Whole Minutes   January 27, 2020 - 7:00 PM    Minutes - January 9, 2020      Page 9 of 9

Special Council Minutes  February 1, 2016 -6:00 pm  Committee Room 1  Whitby Municipal Building      Present:  Mayor Mitchell  Councillor Drumm  Councillor Emm               Councillor Gleed  Councillor Leahy   Councillor Roy   Councillor Yamada (arrived at 6:06 p.m.)    Also Present:  R. Petrie, Chief Administrative Officer  S. Beale, Commissioner of Public Works  P. LeBel, Commissioner of Community & Marketing Services   W. Mar, Commissioner of Legal and By-law Services/Town Solicitor  K. Nix, Commissioner of Corporate Services/Treasurer   A. Lam, Manager of Development Engineering  J. Kittle, Superintendent of Operations (Roads)  C. Harris, Town Clerk  S. Cassel, Deputy Clerk    Regrets:  Councillor Coe (leave of absence)    1.  Declarations of Pecuniary Interest    1.1  There were no declarations of pecuniary interest.      Resolution # 42-16    Moved By Councillor Emm  Seconded By Councillor Leahy    That Council move in-camera in accordance with the provisions of  Procedural By-law # 7072-15 and the Municipal Act, 2001, Section 239  (2) (e) litigation or potential litigation, including matters before  administrative tribunals, affecting the municipality or local board; (f)  advice that is subject to solicitor client privilege, including  communications necessary for that purpose and Section 239 (3.1) for  the purpose of educating or training members.   Special Council Minutes   February 01, 2016 - 6:00 PM      Carried  2.  In Camera Matters    2.1  Confidential Verbal Update by the Commissioner of Community and  Marketing Services  Re: Litigation Matter – IPSC    This portion of the meeting was closed to the public. [Refer to the In  Camera minutes of the meeting - Town Clerk has control and custody.]    3.  Presentations    3.1  Education and Training Session of Council  Presentation by the Commissioner of Public Works  Re: Information on Procedures and Practices with regard to Fences  along Municipal Right-of-Ways     This portion of the meeting was closed to the public. [Refer to the In  Camera minutes of the meeting - Town Clerk has control and custody.]      Resolution # 43-16    Moved By Councillor Leahy  Seconded By Councillor Emm    That Council rise from the In Camera Session of the Special Meeting of  Council.     Carried  4.  Adjournment    4.1  Motion to Adjourn      Resolution # 44-16    Moved By Councillor Leahy  Seconded By Councillor Emm    That the meeting adjourn.    Page 2 of 3  Special Council Minutes   February 01, 2016 - 6:00 PM    Carried    The meeting adjourned at 6:53 p.m.  Christopher Harris, Town Clerk  Don Mitchell, Mayor    Page 3 of 3

Property Standards Appeal Committee Minutes  June 23, 2021 – 3:00 PM  Virtual Meeting        Present:  G. Konorowski, Member   F. Mielewczyk, Chair  R. Peers, Member  G. Shakthi, Member  A. Wray, Member     Also Present:  K. Novia, Staff Liaison, Supervisor, By-law and Animal Services  B. Booth, Senior Municipal Law Enforcement Officer  T. Barnes, Municipal Law Enforcement Officer  N. Newman, Municipal Law Enforcement Officer  H. Oerlemans, Council & Committee Coordinator (Recording  Secretary)    Regrets:  None noted    1.  Call to Order  2.  Disclosures of Interest    2.1  There were no disclosures of interest.  Kate Novia, Supervisor of By-law and Animal Services, addressed the  Committee and appellants and outlined the powers of the Property  Standards Officer. K. Novia explained that the Committee has all of the  powers of the Property Standards Officer and may confirm, rescind, or  modify the Order.    3.  Appeal Hearing    3.1  Property Standards Order Appeal  917 Centre Street South  Appeal # PSA 21-03, File/Order # 20-106390  T. Barnes, Municipal Law Enforcement Officer, provided an overview of  the Property Standards Order issued on March 24, 2021. Mr. Barnes  advised that sections of soffit required repair and that a tree located  close to the garage was dead. He further advised that the Town arborist  advised that the limbs of the dead tree would fail within a year. Mr.   Property Standards Appeal Committee Minutes   June 23, 2021 - 3:00 PM    Barnes stated that the Property Standards Order required the property  owner to remove the tree and repair the soffits.  T. Wilson, the appellant, appeared before the Committee and provided  an overview of his financial situation and requested that the Committee  extend the Property Standards Order for six months.  The Committee excused the appellant, K. Novia, B. Booth, T. Barnes,  and N. Newman from the virtual meeting at 3:11 p.m. and reviewed the  matter. The appellant, K. Novia, B. Booth, T. Barnes, and N. Newman  returned to the meeting at 3:16 p.m.      Recommendation:    Moved By A. Wray    That the Property Standards Order # 20-106390 for the property  municipally known as 917 Centre Street South, be modified and that the  compliance date for the Order be extended to October 31, 2021.    Carried    3.2  Property Standards Order Appeal  560 Bradley Drive  Appeal # PSA 21-04, File/Order # 21-103222  N. Newman, Municipal Law Enforcement Officer, provided an overview  of the Property Standards Order issued on May 5, 2021. Mr. Newman  advised that the deck on the property remained in a state of disrepair  and was missing a hand rail.  A question and answer period ensued between Members of the  Committee and Mr. Newman regarding:  • whether the property was occupied;  • whether there were any immediate health and safety concerns;  • the level of deterioration of the deck; and,  • whether the deck could be taken down.  C. Ball, the appellant, appeared before the Committee and advised that  due to COVID-19, he was unable to access the lumber required to  replace the railing around the deck. Mr. Ball requested that the Property  Standards Order be modified to extend the time for compliance.  A question and answer period ensued between Members of the  Committee and Mr. Ball regarding:  • the age of the youngest occupant of the household;  Page 2 of 3  Property Standards Appeal Committee Minutes   June 23, 2021 - 3:00 PM    • whether the door to the deck could be blocked until it is fixed;  and,  • whether a snow fence could be set up to prevent unwanted  trespassers on the deck.  The Committee excused the appellant, K. Novia, B. Booth, T. Barnes,  and N. Newman from the virtual meeting at 3:31 p.m. and reviewed the  matter. The appellant, K. Novia, B. Booth, T. Barnes, and N. Newman  returned to the meeting at 3:34 p.m.      Recommendation:    Moved By R. Peers    That the Property Standards Order # 20-103222 for the property  municipally known as 560 Bradley Drive, be modified and that the  compliance date for the Order be extended to August 31, 2021.    Carried  4.  Adjournment    4.1  Motion to Adjourn      Recommendation:    Moved By A. Wray    That the meeting adjourn.    Carried    The meeting adjourned at 3:36 p.m.    Secretary, Property Standards Appeal  Committee      Page 3 of 3

Regular Council Minutes  December 13, 2021 - 7:00 PM  Virtual Meeting        Present:  Mayor Mitchell (Participating Electronically)  Councillor Drumm (Participating Electronically)  Councillor Leahy (Participating Electronically)  Councillor Lee (Participating Electronically)  Councillor Mulcahy (Participating Electronically)  Councillor Newman (Participating Electronically)  Councillor Roy (Participating Electronically)  Councillor Yamada (Participating Electronically)    Also Present:  M. Gaskell, Chief Administrative Officer   J. Romano, Commissioner of Community Services  R. Saunders, Commissioner of Planning and Development  D. Speed, Head of Operations & Fire Chief   F. Wong, Commissioner of Financial Services/Treasurer  S. Klein, Director of Strategic Initiatives  J. Long, Head of Organizational Effectiveness  H. Ellis, Executive Advisor to the Mayor  C.
