Councillor Mulcahy did  not take part in the discussion or voting on any matters related to the  Special Council minutes of December 6, 2021.      1.2  Councillor Newman declared a conflict of interest regarding Item 7.9 of  the Regular Council minutes of November 29, 2021, noting that she had  previously declared the conflict at that meeting. Councillor Newman did  not take part in the discussion or voting on any matters related to the  Regular Council minutes of November 29, 2021.    2.  Adoption of Minutes   Regular Council Minutes   December 13, 2021 - 7:00 PM      2.1  Special Council - November 29, 2021  Regular Council - November 29, 2021  Special Council - December 1, 2021  Special Council - December 6, 2021  Having previously declared a conflict of interest, Councillor Newman did  not take part in the discussion or voting on this matter.      Resolution # 344-21    Moved By Councillor Drumm  Seconded By Councillor Lee    That the Regular Council minutes of November 29, 2021 be adopted.    Carried    Having previously declared a conflict of interest, Councillor Mulcahy did  not take part in the discussion or voting on this matter.    Resolution # 345-21    Moved By Councillor Drumm  Seconded By Councillor Lee    That the Special Council minutes of December 6, 2021 be adopted.    Carried    Resolution # 346-21    Moved By Councillor Drumm  Seconded By Councillor Lee    That the Special Council minutes of November 29 and December 1,  2021 be adopted.    Carried  3.  Presentations    3.1  There were no presentations.    Page 2 of 14  Regular Council Minutes   December 13, 2021 - 7:00 PM    4.  Delegations    4.1  There were no delegations.    5.  Correspondence    5.1  There was no correspondence.    6.  Committee of the Whole Report  Planning and Development - December 6, 2021    6.1  Planning and Development Department Report, PL 76-21  Re: Zoning By-law Amendment Application, 870 Columbus Road West,  Richard & Ann Evans, File Number DEV-32-21 (Z-22-21)      Resolution # 347-21    Moved By Councillor Yamada  Seconded By Councillor Mulcahy    1. That Council approve an amendment to extend the temporary  use for a garden suite (File Number: Z-22-21) for a period of  three (3) years at 870 Columbus Road West, and that a By-law to  amend Zoning By-law # 1784, as amended, be brought forward  for Council's consideration; and,  2. That Council authorize the Mayor and Clerk to execute the  amending Site Plan Agreement to extend the permissions for the  garden suite for a period of three (3) years.    Carried    6.2  Planning and Development Report, PL 77-21  Re: Draft Plan of Subdivision and Zoning By-law Amendment  Applications, Abacus Equity Infusion Limited, 7400 Thickson Road  North, File Numbers: DEV-03-20 (SW-2020-01, Z-02-20)     Note: This item was referred at Committee.    7.  Committee of the Whole Report  General Government - December 6, 2021    7.1  Public Works Department, Financial Services Department, and  Community Services Department Joint Report, FS 59-21  Page 3 of 14  Regular Council Minutes   December 13, 2021 - 7:00 PM    Re: T-553-2021 - Supply and Delivery of Work Wear      Resolution # 348-21    Moved By Councillor Roy  Seconded By Councillor Drumm    1. That Tender T-553-2021 be awarded to Mark's Commercial, a  division of Mark's Work Wearhouse Ltd., in the amount of  $190,320.51 (plus applicable taxes) for a three (3) year term for  the supply and delivery of work wear, to be funded annually from  the operating budget;  2. That approval be granted for the option to extend this contract for  two (2) additional one (1) year terms subject to work wear  requirements, budget approval and provided the Successful  Bidder's annual performance, product quality and timely delivery  are satisfactory, at a projected incremental amount of  $126,880.34 (plus applicable taxes and contract cost escalations  for the extension term); and,  3. That the Mayor and Clerk be authorized to execute the contract  documents.    Carried    7.2  Financial Services Department Report, FS 27-21  Re: Update on Property Tax Assessment Appeals and Adjustments      Resolution # 349-21    Moved By Councillor Roy  Seconded By Councillor Drumm    That Report FS 27-21 be received as information.     Carried    7.3  Financial Services Department Report, FS 54-21  Re: 2021 Grant related Procurement Awards  A question and answer period ensued between Members of Council and  Staff regarding:   • details of the Provincial My Main Street Grant program including  the Town's investment in the program and the expected return on  Page 4 of 14  Regular Council Minutes   December 13, 2021 - 7:00 PM    investment for businesses in Downtown Whitby and Downtown  Brooklin; and,   • clarification that there will be two dedicated business  development professionals assigned to Downtown Whitby and  one to Downtown Brooklin to work with local businesses to  submit up to 10 grant applications for new and existing  businesses.       Resolution # 350-21    Moved By Councillor Roy  Seconded By Councillor Drumm    1. That Report No. FS 54-21 be received as information;  2. That, the Town provide the Business Advisory Centre of Durham  a payment of $50,000 for the Town's share of the Provincial My  Main Street Grant, funded from the 2021 operating budget,  account 799-MEDB-3980;  3. That a new service level related to Closed Circuit Television  (CCTV) equipment in Downtown Whitby, at an annual cost of  $2,000 be approved and included in the 2022 operating budget;  and,  4. That a new 2021 capital project, in the amount of $40,000 be  established for a Downtown Whitby CCTV system, funded  $20,000 from the grant received by the Durham Regional Police  Service and $20,000 from the Long Term Finance Reserve.    Carried    7.4  Financial Services Department Report, FS 62-21  Re: Capital Budget and Reserve/Reserve Fund Projection      Resolution # 351-21    Moved By Councillor Roy  Seconded By Councillor Drumm    1. That staff report FS 62-21 be received for information; and,  2. That the Treasurer be authorized to make a lump sum payment,  of up to $20,875,000 to the West Whitby Landowners Group,  funded from the Roads Development Charge reserve fund.    Carried  Page 5 of 14  Regular Council Minutes   December 13, 2021 - 7:00 PM      7.5  Financial Services Department Report, FS 64-21  Re: Temporary Borrowing By-law      Resolution # 352-21    Moved By Councillor Roy  Seconded By Councillor Drumm    That a By-law is brought forward to authorize the external temporary  borrowing of up to $56,681,000 from January 1, 2022 to September 30,  2022, and up to $28,340,000 between October 1, 2022 and December  31, 2022.     Carried    7.6  Financial Services Department Report, FS 66-21  Re: 2022 Interim Tax Billing      Resolution # 353-21    Moved By Councillor Roy  Seconded By Councillor Drumm    That a by-law be brought forward to allow for the Interim Tax Billing for  the 2022 taxation year as outlined in this report FS 66-21.    Carried    7.7  Financial Services Department, and Public Works (Operations) Joint  Report, FS 68-21  Re: Fleet & Equipment Pre-Budget Approval      Resolution # 354-21    Moved By Councillor Roy  Seconded By Councillor Drumm    1. That the Capital Projects listed as "2022 Budget (Delivery in  2022)" and "2022 Budget (Delivery in 2024)" in Table 1 of Report  FS 68-21 be granted pre-budget approval;  Page 6 of 14  Regular Council Minutes   December 13, 2021 - 7:00 PM    2. That the Head of Organizational Effectiveness or Head of  Operations and Treasurer be provided delegated authority to  award the 2021 and 2022 Capital Projects identified in Table 1 of  Report FS 68-21 following a procurement in accordance with the  Purchasing Policy and provided such awards are within budgets;  3. That all awards made under Staff's delegated authority be  summarized and reported to Council after- the-fact; and,  4. That the Mayor and Clerk be authorized to execute the contract  documents.    Carried    7.8  Public Works Department (Engineering) Report, PW 39-21  Re: Region of Durham's Proposed Study of the Current Policy/Practice  for Street Lighting on Regional Roads      Resolution # 355-21    Moved By Councillor Roy  Seconded By Councillor Drumm    1. That Council endorse the draft Terms of Reference and approach  for the Region of Durham's Proposed Study of the Current  Policy/Practice for Street Lighting on Regional Roads;  2. That the Region's current practice with respect to street lighting  on Regional roads, as described in the Region's Works  Committee Report # 2021-W-36 (refer to Attachment 1), continue  to prevail until the Region's proposed study is completed and any  changes are approved and implemented;  3. That Staff review and report to Council as to the feasibility and  cost for assumption by the Town of street lighting for Taunton  Road between Country Lane and Cochrane Street, or as  otherwise directed by Staff, given the upcoming opening of  Thermea Spa, with the report to be provided by the end of Q1 of  2022; and,   4. That Public Works Report PW 39-21 be forwarded to the Region  of Durham.    Carried    7.9  Public Works (Engineering) Department Report, PW 40-21  Re: Update Traffic By-law 1862-85: No Stopping on Foundry Lane,  Tidewater Crescent and Wetherburn Drive      Page 7 of 14  Regular Council Minutes   December 13, 2021 - 7:00 PM    Resolution # 356-21    Moved By Councillor Roy  Seconded By Councillor Drumm    1. That Council approve an amendment to Traffic By-law # 1862-85,  as identified in Attachment 2 to Report PW 40-21; and,  2. That a by-law to amend By-law # 1862-85 be brought forward for  the consideration of Council.    Carried    7.10 Public Works (Engineering) Department, and Financial Services  Department Joint Report, PW 43-21  Re: Development Review Fee Study Update – Engineering Review and  Inspection Fees      Resolution # 357-21    Moved By Councillor Roy  Seconded By Councillor Drumm    1. That the Development Fees Review Study prepared by Watson &  Associates Economists Ltd. (Attachment 1) be received for  information;  2. That the proposed amendments to the Engineering Review and  Inspection Fees included in Attachment 2 of Report PW 43-21 be  approved;  3. That the recommended fees take effect on January 1, 2022;  4. That all the Engineering Review and Inspection Fees be indexed  by 2.5% on January 1 of  each year;  5. That the Town Clerk be directed to bring forward a by-law to  amend the Fees and Charges By-law to give effect to the  recommendations contained in Report PW 43-21; and,  6. That Council approve one additional staff resource for each of the  following full-time positions, including the associated capital and  operating costs identified in Tables 2 and 3 of Report PW 43-21:  • Water Resource Engineer (Development)  • Program Manager (Development)  • Development Services Technician 2 (Development)  • Supervisor of Development Construction  • Construction Inspector 2  • Construction Inspector 1  Page 8 of 14  Regular Council Minutes   December 13, 2021 - 7:00 PM      Carried    7.11 Chief Administrative Officer Report, CAO 33-21  Re: Whitby Climate Change Master Plan  A question and answer period ensued between Members of Council and  Staff regarding:   • the importance of collaboration between all levels of government  in order to develop a unified strategy to address climate change;   • strong leadership by the Town in developing programs to address  climate change;   • confirmation that the Town is the first municipality in the Region  to join both the Race to Resiliency and Race to Zero programs;   • engaging residents in developing climate change solutions and  the importance of resident participation; and,   • how the ISeeChange app will serve as an important engagement  tool and how the tool will be leveraged.       Resolution # 358-21    Moved By Councillor Roy  Seconded By Councillor Drumm    1. That Council receive Report CAO 33-21 for information; and,  2. That Council commit the Town of Whitby to join the Race to  Resiliency and Race to Zero.     Carried    7.12 Office of the Chief Administrative Officer, and Financial Services  Department Joint Report, CAO 34-21  Re: Zero Carbon Whitby Costing Study Pre-Budget Approval      Resolution # 359-21    Moved By Councillor Roy  Seconded By Councillor Drumm    1. That Report CAO 34-21 be received for information;  2. That Council provide pre-budget approval of the planned 2022  capital project 55227607 in the amount of $161,000 to complete a  Page 9 of 14  Regular Council Minutes   December 13, 2021 - 7:00 PM    Zero Carbon Whitby Costing Study funded from the Long Term  Finance Reserve;  3. That Staff be directed to prepare a Zero Carbon Whitby Costing  Study to be presented in May 2022 in alignment with the 2023  budget cycle; and,  4. That Council authorize staff to extend the existing Zero Carbon  Whitby Contract and retain Sustainable Solutions Group to  complete the Zero Carbon Whitby Costing Study in the amount of  $158,000 (plus HST) in accordance with Section 7.1 of the  Purchasing Policy.    Carried    7.13 Office of the Chief Administrative Officer, Public Works (Engineering),  and Legal and Enforcement Services Department Joint Report, CAO 35- 21  Re: Electric Vehicle Charging Station User Policy and Traffic By-law  Amendment      Resolution # 360-21    Moved By Councillor Roy  Seconded By Councillor Drumm    1. That Council approve the Draft Electric Vehicle Charging Station  User Policy as outlined in Attachment 1;  2. That Council approve the proposed amendment to Traffic By-law  # 1862-85 to incorporate the changes, as identified in Attachment  2; and,  3. That a By-law to amend By-law 1862-85 be brought forward for  the consideration of Council.    Carried    7.14 Office of the Chief Administrative Officer, and Financial Services  Department Joint Report, CAO 36-21  Re: Climate Change Mitigation Plan Contract Award      Resolution # 361-21    Moved By Councillor Roy  Seconded By Councillor Drumm    Page 10 of 14  Regular Council Minutes   December 13, 2021 - 7:00 PM    That Council authorize staff to extend the existing Climate Change  Adaptation Plan Contract and retain Sustainable Solutions Group to  complete the Climate Change Mitigation Plan in the amount of $122,000  plus HST in accordance with Section 7.1 of the Purchasing Policy.    Carried  8.  Notice of Motion    8.1  Warming Centre at a Town Facility  Councillor Roy introduced a motion regarding establishing a warming  centre at a Town facility.   A question and answer period ensued between Members of Council and  Staff regarding:   • the need for a dedicated warming centre in each local  municipality in the Region;   • examining best practices from the City of Toronto regarding  operating warming centres;   • the importance of providing resources at warming centres to  assist people with finding shelter;   • operational challenges associated with housing people overnight;  and,   • whether the warming centre will be operated by Town Staff,  Region of Durham Staff, or volunteers.       Resolution # 362-21    Moved By Councillor Roy  Seconded By Councillor Newman    That Staff be directed to coordinate with the Region of Durham's Social  Services Department and local not-for-profit agencies dedicated to  helping the homeless and vulnerable populations to establish a warming  centre at a Town facility during the winter months.    Carried  9.  New and Unfinished Business    There was no new and unfinished business.  10.  By-Laws  That the following by-laws be passed:  Page 11 of 14  Regular Council Minutes   December 13, 2021 - 7:00 PM      10.1 By-law # 7823-21, being a by-law to designate certain portions of a  registered Plan of Subdivision (SW-2013-02) as not being subject of  Part Lot Control.      10.2 By-law # 7824-21, being a by-law to designate certain portions of a  registered Plan of Subdivision (SW-2013-04) as not being subject of  Part Lot Control.      10.3 By-law # 7825-21, being a by-law to Authorize the temporary borrowing  of an amount not to exceed $56,681,000 from January 1 to September  30, 2022, and $28,340,000 from October 1 to December 31, 2022, to  meet current expenditures of The Corporation of the Town of Whitby  (the Town) for the year, until taxes are collected, and other revenues  received.      Refer to FS 64-21, Temporary Borrowing By-law      10.4 By-law # 7826-21, being a by-law to amend the Fees and Charges By- law # 7220-17, as amended.     Refer to PW 43-21, Development Review Fee Study Update –  Engineering Review and Inspection Fees      10.5 By-law # 7827-21, being a by-law to adopt a Community Improvement  Plan for the Downtown Whitby Community Improvement Project Area.     Refer to CAO 26-21, Downtown Whitby Community Improvement Plan  Grant Program Uptake and Recommended Amendments      10.6 By-law # 7828-21, being a by-law to Amend By-law 1862-85, being a  By-law to Regulate Traffic on the Highways and on Certain Private  Roadways in the Town of Whitby.     Refer to PW 40-21, Update Traffic By-law 1862-85: No Stopping on  Foundry Lane, Tidewater Crescent and Wetherburn Drive       10.7 By-law # 7829-21, being a by-law to provide for an interim tax levy for  the year 2022.     Refer to FS 66-21, 2022 Interim Tax Billing      Page 12 of 14  Regular Council Minutes   December 13, 2021 - 7:00 PM    10.8 By-law # 7830-21, being a by-law to amend the Traffic By-law # 1862- 85.     Refer to CAO 35-21, Electric Vehicle Charging Station User Policy &  Traffic By-Law Amendment      10.9 By-law # 7831-21, being a by-law to dedicate Parts 1 and 2 on 40R- 31462 as a Public Highway (Kendalwood Road).      10.10 By-law  # 7832-21, being a by-law to dedicate Parts 1 and 3 on Plan  40R-31261 as a Public Highway (Ash Street).      10.11 By-law # 7833-21, being a by-law to adopt Amendment Number 123 to  the Official Plan of the Town of Whitby.     Refer to PL 59-21, Proposed Official Plan Amendment – Transportation  Amendments, File No. DEV-06-21 (OPA-2021-W/01)      10.12 By-law # 7834-21, being a by-law to Amend Procedure By-law # 7462- 18 to permit Members of Council to participate electronically in Council  and Committee meetings if they are unwell in consideration of public  health best practices, or if they are physically unable to attend in- person due to injury or other health consideration.      10.13 By-law # 7835-21, being a by-law to amend By-law #1784, as  amended, being the Zoning By-law for the Town of Whitby.     Refer to PL 76-21, Zoning By-Law Amendment Application, 870  Columbus Road West, Richard & Ann Evans, File No. DEV-32-21 (Z- 22-21)      10.14 By-law # 7836-21, being a by-law to Amend the Public Nuisance By- law # 6714-13, as amended.      10.15 By-law # 7837-21, being a by-law to Amend the Town Lands  Encroachment By-law # 7389-18.      Resolution # 363-21    Moved By Councillor Leahy  Seconded By Councillor Newman    Page 13 of 14  Regular Council Minutes   December 13, 2021 - 7:00 PM    That leave be granted to introduce By-laws # 7823-21 to # 7837-21 and  to dispense with the reading of the by-laws by the Clerk and that the  same be considered read and passed and that the Mayor and the Clerk  sign the same and the Seal of the Corporation be thereto affixed.    Carried  11.  Confirmatory By-Law    11.1 Confirmatory By-law      Resolution # 364-21    Moved By Councillor Lee  Seconded By Councillor Drumm    That leave be granted to introduce a by-law and to dispense with the  reading of the by-law by the Clerk to confirm the proceedings of the  Council of the Town of Whitby at its regular meeting held on December  13, 2021 and the same be considered read and passed and that the  Mayor and the Clerk sign the same and the Seal of the Corporation be  thereto affixed.    Carried  12.  Adjournment    12.1 Motion to Adjourn      Moved By Councillor Newman  Seconded By Councillor Mulcahy    That the meeting adjourn. filename: Whitby Diversity and Inclusion Advisory Committee-03 Oct 2019.pdf
category: Whitby Diversity and Inclusion Advisory Committee
text: Whitby Diversity and Inclusion Advisory Committee Minutes  October 3, 2019 – 7:15 PM  Committee Room One  Whitby Town Hall    Present:  Mayline Brown, Chair (arrived at 7:26 p.m.)  Andrea Cecchetto, Vice-Chair  Cheryl Frayne  Brianna Nelson  Catherine Philogene   Ayse Yuksel     Also Present:  Councillor Shahid, Mayor's Designate    Mallory Dawson, Whitby Public Library Representative  Kim Evans, Staff Liaison, Supervisor, Seniors Services  Heather Oerlemans, Council and Committee Coordinator  (Recording Secretary)    Regrets:  Vivek Singh    1.  Disclosures of Interest    1.1  There were no disclosures of interest.    2.  Approval of Previous Minutes    2.1  Minutes - September 5, 2019      Recommendation:    Moved By Cheryl Frayne    That the Whitby Diversity and Inclusion Advisory Committee minutes of  September 5, 2019 be approved.    Carried  3.  Presentations    3.1  There were no presentations.    4.  Delegations     Whitby Diversity and Inclusion Advisory Committee Minutes   October 03, 2019 - 7:15 PM    4.1  There were no delegations.    5.  General Business and Reports    5.1  Event Review and Participation  Harvest Festival - September 14, 2019  Ayse Yuksel provided a recap of the event and advised that the apple  give-away was a success. It was the consensus of the Committee to  send a thank you card to Nature's Bounty for their donation of the  apples.  School Presentation - Fall 2019  Cheryl Frayne advised that the school presentation at Robert Munsch  Public School would not be finalized until 2020.  A brief discussion ensued regarding contacting Trafalgar Castle School  as a location for hosting a Fall 2019 school presentation.  Annual Diversity Conference, Town of Ajax - November 16, 2019  Discussion ensued regarding presentation topics for the Annual  Diversity Conference which included:  • Whitby's translation service at the front desk;  • installation of a rainbow crosswalk;  • Council's land acknowledgement;  • Whitby's Age and Youth Strategies;  • an overview of events that the Whitby Diversity and Inclusion  Advisory Committee has participated in; and,  • school presentations.  Kim Evans and Catherine Philogene advised that they would prepare a  ten-slide PowerPoint presentation for the Conference for the Committee  to review at the November Committee meeting.      5.2  Whitby Diversity and Inclusion Advisory Committee Promotional Items  Kim Evans advised that the promotional items would be purchased at a  later date once the Town's branding was released.      5.3  Whitby Diversity and Inclusion Advisory Committee Public Survey  Andrea Cecchetto requested feedback from the Committee regarding  the draft Whitby Diversity and Inclusion Advisory Committee Public  Survey.  Page 2 of 4  Whitby Diversity and Inclusion Advisory Committee Minutes   October 03, 2019 - 7:15 PM    Discussion ensued regarding:  • removing questions 3, 16, and 21 - 24 from the draft survey;  • providing options for diversity for question 2; and,  • ensuring question 11 contains the updated categories in the  Ontario Human Rights Code.  Ms. Cecchetto requested that Members email their suggested changes  to the draft survey for review.      5.4  Diversity and Inclusion Communities of Practices: Durham Group and  Ontario Group  Kim Evans advised that the Diversity and Inclusion Communities of  Practices: Durham Group and Ontario Group met on September 12 and  September 18 respectively. Ms. Evans advised that the purpose of the  Groups was to create a collaboration of information sharing between  municipalities and across Ontario regarding best practices for diversity  and inclusion initiatives.      5.5  Proclamation Suggestions: Winter 2019-2020  Councillor Shahid advised that October was Islamic History Month and  suggested Islamic History Month could be the Committee's October  proclamation.  Kim Evans advised that the Whitby Multicultural Calendar had been  ordered for 2020.    6.  Correspondence    6.1  Durham Multifaith Thanksgiving  Cheryl Frayne distributed flyers for information regarding the Durham  Multifaith Thanksgiving celebration on October 20, 2019 from 2:00 p.m.  to 4:00 p.m. at the Heber Downs Conservation Area picnic shelter.    7.  Council Update    7.1  Councillor Shahid provided updates regarding:  • the success of the Wild Nellies celebration of women event on  September 28, 2019 at the Centennial Building;  • a Land Acknowledgement statement would now precede every  Council meeting; and,  • a request for Committee feedback for selecting Mayor and  Council's holiday parade 'float song'.    Page 3 of 4  Whitby Diversity and Inclusion Advisory Committee Minutes   October 03, 2019 - 7:15 PM    8.  Other Business    8.1  Whitby Public Library Update  Mallory Dawson provided Whitby Public Library updates which included:  • conducting a diversity audit on the Library's Children's Collection;  • an after school program in partnership with the Highland Towers  Apartments on White Oaks Court on October 17, 2019; and,  • downtown businesses celebrating Ontario Public Library Week by  offering 'perks' to patrons who presented their library card  between October 18 to 28.    9.  Next Meeting    9.1  Thursday, November 7, 2019 - 7:15 p.m.  Boardroom, Whitby Seniors' Activity Centre  801 Brock Street South    10.  Adjournment    10.1 Motion to Adjourn      Recommendation:    Moved By Andrea Cecchetto    That the meeting adjourn.    Carried    The meeting adjourned at 8:49 p.m.    H. Oerlemans, Council and Committee  Coordinator  M. Brown, Committee Chair    Page 4 of 4

1    Special Council Minutes    September 16, 2024, 6:15 p.m.  Council Chambers  Whitby Town Hall    Present:  Mayor Roy  Councillor Bozinovski  Councillor Cardwell  Councillor Leahy (Virtual Attendance)  Councillor Lee  Councillor Lundquist  Councillor Mulcahy  Councillor Shahid  Councillor Yamada  Also Present:  M. Gaskell, Chief Administrative Officer  M. Hickey, Fire Chief  S. Klein, Director of Strategic Initiatives  J. Long, Head of Organizational Effectiveness  J. Romano, Commissioner of Community Services  F. Santaguida, Commissioner of Legal and Enforcement  Services/Town Solicitor  R. Saunders, Commissioner of Planning and Development  F. Wong, Commissioner of Financial Services/Treasurer  M. Dodge, Executive Advisor to the Mayor  C. Harris, Town Clerk  K. Douglas, Sr. Legislative Specialist (Recording Secretary)  _____________________________________________________________________    1.  Call To Order: The Mayor  2.  Call of the Roll: The Clerk  3.  Declarations of Conflict of Interest  There were no declarations of conflict of interest.  4.  Correspondence       2  4.1  Correspondence #2024-490 received from Next Plumbing & Hydronics  Supplies Inc. regarding Development Charges Complaint - Unit 1, 1450  Victoria Street East  Refer to Item 5.1, FS 25-24  It was the consensus of Council to move into closed session to hear Item  5.1, FS 25-24, at this time.   5.  Closed Session  This portion of the minutes are closed to the public. [Refer to the Closed Minutes  - Town Clerk has control and custody.]  Moved by Councillor Shahid  Seconded by Councillor Lundquist  That Council move in-camera in accordance with Procedure By-law # 8081-24,  Closed Meeting Policy G 040, and the Municipal Act, 2001, Section 239 (2)(e)  litigation or potential litigation, including matters before administrative tribunals,  affecting the municipality or local board, (f) advice that is subject to solicitor-client  privilege, including communications necessary for that purpose, and (k) a  position, plan, procedure, criteria or instruction to be applied to any negotiations  carried on or to be carried on by or on behalf of the municipality or local board.   Carried    5.1  FS 25-24, Confidential Financial Services Department and Legal and  Enforcement Services Department Joint Report  Re: Development Charge Complaint - Unit 1, 1450 Victoria Street East -  Settlement Offer  6.  Rising and Reporting  Motion to Rise  Moved by Councillor Mulcahy  Seconded by Councillor Cardwell  That Council rise from the closed portion of the meeting.   Carried    6.1  Reporting Out       3  Mayor Roy advised that during the closed portion of the meeting, Council  received advice that is subject to solicitor-client privilege regarding a  matter of potential litigation and discussed a position to be applied to  negotiations to be carried on by the municipality.  FS 25-24, Confidential Financial Services Department and Legal and  Enforcement Services Department Joint Report          Re: Development Charge Complaint - Unit 1, 1450 Victoria Street East -  Settlement Offer  Resolution # 165-24  Moved by Councillor Mulcahy  Seconded by Councillor Shahid  1. That Council authorize the Mayor and Clerk to execute Minutes of  Settlement between the Town and the Next Plumbing & Hydronics  Supplies Inc., as outlined in Staff Report FS 25-24, all in a form  satisfactory to the Commissioners of Financial Services and  Treasurer, and Legal and Enforcement Services/Town Solicitor;  and,  2. That Council direct Staff to develop a procedural framework for  consistently determining the appropriate non-residential rate in  support of Development Charges By-law #7748-21.  Carried    7.  Delegations  7.1  Matthew Rutledge, Fogler, Rubinoff LLP representing Next Plumbing and  Hydronics Supplies Inc. (In-Person Attendance)  Re: Correspondence #2024-490 received from Next Plumbing &  Hydronics Supplies Inc. regarding Development Charges Complaint - Unit  1, 1450 Victoria Street East  Refer to Item 4.1, Correspondence #2024-490  Matthew Rutledge, Fogler, Rubinoff LLP, withdrew their delegation  request.  8.  Confirmatory By-law  Resolution # 166-24       4  Moved by Councillor Mulcahy  Seconded by Councillor Cardwell  That leave be granted to introduce a by-law and to dispense with the reading of  the by-law by the Clerk to confirm the proceedings of the Council of the Town of  Whitby at its special meeting held on September 16, 2024 and the same be  considered read and passed and that the Mayor and the Clerk sign the same and  the Seal of the Corporation be thereto affixed.  Carried    9.  Adjournment  Moved by Councillor Lee  Seconded by Councillor Mulcahy  That the meeting adjourn.  Carried  The meeting adjourned at 6:28 p.m.            Christopher Harris, Town Clerk    Elizabeth Roy, Mayor

M. Gaskell, Chief Administrative Officer and P. Spratt, Strategic Plan  Advisor, provided a PowerPoint Presentation regarding strategic  priorities, issues and challenges for the Town of Whitby. Highlights of  the presentation included:  • Council's goals, as well as an overview of the Corporate Strategic  Plan Project;  • the Town of Whitby's Mission Statement, Vision Statement and  Values; and,  • strategic priorities including goals and objectives related to the  organization, customer service and employee satisfaction.    C. Siopis, Manager, Corporate Communications, provided a PowerPoint  Presentation regarding communications and public engagement.  Highlights of the presentation included:  • background information related to the creation of the Corporate  Communications Division;  • an overview of Corporate Communications including, branding,  digital media and special events;  • an overview of the Corporate Communications goals,  communications channels, publications, social media, media  relations, and special events; and,  • the phases of the Community Engagement Strategy, the  Community Open House Procedure and corporate projects.    Guy Giorno, Integrity Commissioner, provided a PowerPoint  presentation which included an overview of the Municipal Conflict of  Interest Act and the Council Code of Conduct. C. Harris, Town Clerk, provided a PowerPoint presentation regarding  meeting efficiencies and the Town's Procedure By-law. ITEMS FOR CONSIDERATION BY COUNCIL IN COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE    3.1  Report, CAO 9-13  Re: Appointment Procedure for Filling Vacancy – Town Councillor North  Ward 1  Discussion ensued regarding the report. That Report CAO 9-13 of the Chief Administrative Officer be  received;  2. SEE FOLLOWING MOTION  Moved By Councillor Mitchell  That the main motion be amended by adding the following as item 3 and  the recommendation be renumbered accordingly:  That the Appointment Procedure be amended to reflect that all  candidates shall be placed on the slate of candidates, removing the  Council nomination process.  CARRIED  The main motion, as amended, was then CARRIED.  Moved By Councillor Coe    Page 2 of 7  Special Council Minutes   September 23, 2013 -5:30 PM    That Committee of the Whole recess until 6:00 p.m.  CARRIED  Committee of the Whole resumed at 6:00 p.m.    3.2  Planning Report, PL 90-13  Re: Official Plan Review - Proposed Draft Amendment to the Whitby  Official Plan: Urban Land Uses (OPA-2007-W/04)  R. Short, Commissioner of Planning, introduced Report PL 90-13 the  Proposed Draft Amendment to the Whitby Official Plan, advising this is  the second of four proposed updates to the plan. Mr. Short outlined the  timeline for the review.   Nick McDonald, Meridian Consulting, made a presentation regarding the  proposed draft amendments. Mr. McDonald highlighted a number of  revisions to the document including technical and wording changes, new  definitions, mapping changes, revisions to housing policies, updates in  regards to changes as a result of OPA 90, and other revisions to reflect  the current requirements of the Official Plan of the Region of Durham  and the Provincial Policy Statement (PPS).  A detailed question and answer period ensued regarding low density for  new residential areas, intensification areas, industrial and prestige  industrial areas, health precincts, urban squares, alternate uses of  parkland dedication, possible restrictions to mixed use designations.  Public delegations were introduced at this time.   Niomie Massey, Madison Group, 369 Rimrock Road, Toronto, made a  delegation regarding the re-designation of mixed use area lands to  major commercial within the Brooklin major central area to consolidate  major commercial uses as referred to in schedule 2 e) of the draft plan  relating to the area of Roybrook Drive and the previously identified  alignment of Highway 407, which impacts the remaining lands north of  Highway 407 and Baldwin Street. Ms. Massey questioned why only a  portion of OPA 85 was incorporated into the draft plan and sought  clarification of the commercial area and employment land designation.  Ms. Massey expressed interest in the proposed boundary for the central  area. Ms. Massey commented that the West Whitby Secondary Plan will  provide for a review of the commercial component as well as the  proposed boundary for the central area. Ms. Massey requested  clarification that this study will satisfy the requirements under the  Provincial Growth Plan in relation to employment lands and related  Regional Official Plan Amendments. Ms. Massey requested further  Page 3 of 7  Special Council Minutes   September 23, 2013 -5:30 PM    clarification of section 4.6.3.3.6 referencing prestige industrial uses and  limited commercial uses adjacent to Highway 407. N. McDonald,  consultant, clarified that the Brooklin Secondary Plan addresses OPA 85  commercial and employment lands and that updated maps will be  included in future versions of the draft plan.  Matthew Cory, Malone Givens Parsons Limited, 140 Renfrew Drive,  Suite 201, Markham made a delegation on behalf of the Brooklin North  Landowners Group (BNLG). Mr. Cory advised they have reviewed the  first amendment as well as the current draft, and it is their preference to  wait until the additional amendments come forward in order to review  the plan in its entirety.  Bryce Jordan, GHD Consulting and Planning, Whitby made a delegation  on behalf of the West Whitby Land Owners Group. Mr. Jordan referred  to section 4.7.3.10 of the draft plan in relation to policies regarding  surplus school sites and integration where possible with other  community facilities. Mr. Jordan expressed concern that only larger  school sites would be permitted under this policy and requested that this  section of the policy be reviewed. N. McDonald, consultant, advised the  intent of the draft amendment was not to prescribe a larger school site  and this portion of the policy will be reviewed together with further  consultation with the Durham District School Board.  Discussion ensued regarding growth targets in compliance with the  Provincial Growth Plan; necessary amendments due to revised  provincial housing requirements as well as the Region of Durham ten  year housing plan; surplus schools and proposed policy that such sites  be utilized for other community uses; interpretation of cash-in-lieu of  parking and section 4.2.3.8 subsection j) in relation to parking  accommodation in part in a municipal parking lot; identification of  appropriate locations for general and prestige industrial areas, including  business parks; and section 4.8.3.7 whether recreational facilities should  be restricted in proximity to Brock Street and Baldwin Street. It was  requested that Brooklin Concrete be notified of this amendment due to  the recommendations of section 4.6.3.5.5. Staff was requested to clarify  these items for the future draft plan.  Members of Council were provided with a written submission from  Patrick Foran, Aird & Berlis dated September 23, 2013 on behalf of his  client, Dr. H. Weingarten, owner of lands located at the southeast corner  of Springwood Street and Dundas Street East, Whitby. Staff were  requested to review this letter in reference to section 4.2.5.3, and the  impact of the policy changes on the development of the land.  Members of Council were provided with a written submission from  Michael Bissett, Bousfields Inc. dated Septemer 23, 2013 on behalf of  Page 4 of 7  Special Council Minutes   September 23, 2013 -5:30 PM    Nordeagle Developments Inc. He states that the Town should defer any  decision respecting the lands bound by Victoria Street, Gordon Street,  Nordeagle Avenue, and Montecorte Street until such time as studies  outlined in proposed Policy 8C.3.2 are carried out and appropriately  implemented into the Whitby Official Plan.  Moved by Councillor Coe    1. That Planning Report Item No. PL 90-13 be received for information;  and,  2. That the Planning Department report back regarding a  recommended Official Plan Amendment following the consideration  of input from the public, commenting agencies and departments.  CARRIED    Moved By Councillor Coe    That Council rise out of Committee of the Whole and report to Council. A question and answer period ensued regarding:   details about notification for public engagement meetings;   details about traffic calming signage; and,   concerns about traffic calming measures and consideration for  accessibility devices.  5.  Delegations  There were no delegations.  6.  General Business and Reports  6.1  2024 Accessibility Plan Update  Ms. Cotton stated that the 2024 Accessibility Plan update would be  brought forward at the June 3, 2025 Accessibility Advisory Committee  meeting for information.   6.2  Accessibility Improvement Grant Application  Having previously declared a conflict of interest, Michael Richards did not  take part in the discussion or voting regarding this matter.  Michele Cotton advised that an Accessibility Improvement Grant  application was submitted by Landmark Cinemas Whitby for the Lead  Grant Program. Ms. Cotton provided an overview of the application which  included:       3   requesting a matching grant of $10,000;   installing Adobe Accessibility Solutions for Cinemas which provides  narrative audio, closed captioning for patrons who are hearing  impaired, and descriptive video for patrons who are visually  impaired;   the goal of providing equal access to entertainment and enhancing  community engagement; and,   the overall cost for the equipment being approximately $95,000.  Paul Scott stated that the Lead Grant Program is available for small  businesses and provided details about the definition of a small business.  Mr. Scott advised that the Communication and Customer Service  Subcommittee reviewed the application and recommends that the  Accessibility Advisory Committee approve the Accessibility Improvement  Grant application for the Lead Grant Program on the condition that  Landmark Cinemas Whitby meets the eligibility requirements.  Recommendation:  Moved by Adam Lamplugh  That the Accessibility Advisory Committee supports the recommendation  put forward by the Communication and Customer Service Subcommittee  regarding the Accessibility Improvement Grant Application submitted by  Landmark Cinemas Whitby.   Carried    6.3  National AccessAbility Week  Michele Cotton provided an update regarding National AccessAbility Week  Town activities which included:   the National AccessAbility Week flag raising ceremony at Town  Hall on May 26, 2025 beginning at 9:30 a.m.;   the Staff screening of the film Advantage Gained on May 28, 2025  at Town Hall;   a public screening of the film Advantage Gained on May 29, 2025  at the Whitby Public Library; and,       4   a Travelling Roadshow activity whereby Town Staff participate in  simulated activities and obstacles to better understand the Town's  accessibility features.  6.4  Subcommittee Updates  Paul Scott provided an update regarding the Communication and  Customer Service Subcommittee which included reviewing the  Accessibility Improvement Grant application received from Landmark  Cinemas Whitby.  Michele Cotton advised that the Site Plans and Built Environment  Subcommittee did not meet in April and therefore there was no update.  7.  Council Update  Councillor Shahid provided an update regarding:   Bike Month activities hosted by Durham Region;   the Region's Community Growth and Economic Development Committee  marketing campaign for Whitby's tourist destinations and events; and,   proposed amendments to the Private Transportation Services By-law  regarding accessible taxis.  8.  Other Business  8.1  Advisory Committee Code of Conduct  Michele Cotton provided information about Advisory Committee Members'  code of conduct and best practices for social media posts. Ms. Cotton  reminded Members to ensure their social media posts remain non-partisan  and to avoid associating their social media activity with the Accessibility  Advisory Committee.  9.  Next Meeting  Tuesday, June 3, 2025 - 7:00 p.m.  10.  Adjournment  Recommendation:  Moved by Adam Lamplugh  That the meeting adjourn.  Carried       5  The meeting adjourned at 8:40 p.m.

MINUTES OF THE SPECIAL MEETING OF THE COUNCIL OF THE CORPORATION OF  THE TOWN OF WHITBY HELD ON WEDNESDAY, APRIL 7, 2010 AT THE HOUR OF 7:00  P.M. IN THE MEETING HALL OF THE WHITBY MUNICIPAL BUILDING AS CALLED BY THE  HEAD OF COUNCIL PRESENT: Mayor Perkins  Mayor Perkins in the Chair Councillor Coe Councillor Drumm Councillor Mitchell Councillor Pitchforth Councillor Roy Councillor Scott ABSENT: Councillor Emm STAFF PRESENT: R. Petrie, Chief Administrative Officer  S. Beale, Director of Public Works S. Edwards, S. Edwards, Manager of Parks, Marina, Long Range  Planning, Tourism & Culture R. Short, Director of Planning D. Wilcox, Town Clerk M. Pettit, Deputy Clerk CALL TO ORDER Mayor Perkins called the meeting to order at 7:00 p.m. 1. DISCLOSURES OF INTEREST There were no disclosures of interest. RESOLUTION NO. 125-10 MOVED by Councillor Coe Seconded by Councillor Mitchell That Council resolve itself into Committee of the Whole with Councillor Coe,  Chair of Planning & Development Committee, in the Chair for the purpose of  considering a Proposed Draft Official Plan Amendment West Whitby Secondary  Plan (Official Plan Review) (File OPA-2009-W/03). CARRIED Councillor Coe in the Chair.  MINUTES OF THE SPECIAL MEETING OF THE COUNCIL OF THE CORPORATION OF  THE TOWN OF WHITBY HELD ON WEDNESDAY, APRIL 7, 2010 AT THE HOUR OF 7:00  P.M. IN THE MEETING HALL OF THE WHITBY MUNICIPAL BUILDING AS CALLED BY THE  HEAD OF COUNCIL 2. PUBLIC MEETING The Town Clerk provided a review of the Public Meeting process for the benefit of the  audience. 3. ITEM FOR CONSIDERATION BY COUNCIL IN COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE 3.1 Planning Report PL 41-10 TOWN OF WHITBY Proposed Draft Official Plan Amendment West Whitby Secondary Plan (Official Plan Reviews) R. Short, Director of Planning introduced the item.  Nick MacDonald, Partner,  Meridian Planning Consultants, and Karen Nasmith from planningAlliance, who  have been retained to assist the Town of Whitby with its Official Plan Review  provided a brief powerpoint presentation. A question and answer period ensued. Chair Coe declared the meeting to be a public meeting and invited submissions  from the public. Ron Gallagher, 4700 Country Lane, appeared before Committee and inquired  why the highest density was located at Country Lane and Taunton Road as  Country Lane is used extensively for pleasure purposes and this will have  serious impacts.  Mr. Gallagher suggests that high density be moved from  Country Lane.  Mr. Short advised that his comments have been noted and  Planning staff will review the matter. Terry German, 65 Lakeridge Road South, appeared before Committee, and  asked for clarification on the land uses in and around Lakeridge Road and what  the cost sharing of servicing will mean to residents. Sam Mitzi, 1250 Dundas Street, appeared before Committee, and advised he  objects to the designation of his property as being environmentally sensitive as  the soil has not been cleaned up.  Mr. Short advised Mr. Mitzi that if he can get a  letter from the Ministry of Natural Resources supporting this, to please forward it  to the Town. Chris Leeder, 610 Lyndebrook Road, appeared before Committee, and advised  that it was his understanding that these plans were not to impact existing  neighbourhoods and he has concerns that he will be impacted by increased traffic and that this plan will have an impact on property values.  Mr. Leeder  asked the consultants to have regard for existing landowners.  Mr. Short advised  that his comments have been noted and Planning staff will review the matter.  MINUTES OF THE SPECIAL MEETING OF THE COUNCIL OF THE CORPORATION OF  THE TOWN OF WHITBY HELD ON WEDNESDAY, APRIL 7, 2010 AT THE HOUR OF 7:00  P.M. IN THE MEETING HALL OF THE WHITBY MUNICIPAL BUILDING AS CALLED BY THE  HEAD OF COUNCIL Jim McGrorey, 18 Kimberly Drive, appeared before Committee, and advised that  he has concerns about the significant realignment requirements for Coronation  Road that are noted in the plan.  Mr. McGrorey suggests that the consultants  review alternatives that don't require such extensive changes.  Mr. Short advised  that his comments have been noted and planning staff will review the matter. David Airdrie, 128 Halls Road North, appeared before Committee, and asked for  clarification on the meaning of Prestige Industrial and noted that his house in  included in the Gateway area and how does that change from industrial.  Mr.  Short advised that this means a desire for corporate prestige office towers or low  rise residential condos. Jackie Scott, 25 Lakeridge Road, appeared before Committee, and inquired who  is bringing in the services to Almond Village.  Clarification was provided that the  sewer services are not provided by the Town.  Ms. Scott advised that she  believed that sewer services have been grandfathered into her contract. Chuck Quantrill, 152 Michael Boulevard, appeared before Committee, and  inquired about the Burns Street Extension asking if there is an alternative to  servicing the industrial section without bringing it through a residential section.   Mr. Short advised that Burns Street is a designated arterial road and the plan will  protect this alignment as the community grows. Carolyn Goodwin, 27 Lakeridge Road, appeared before Committee, and advised  she has concerns about the development of sewers in Almond Village and water  displacement from the surrounding highways.  S. Beale responded that highway  developments will require storm management systems which will be reviewed by  the Town, the Region, and Conversation Authority (CLOCA).  Ms. Goodwin also  expressed concern about the road network.  The meeting recessed at 9:06 p.m. The meeting reconvened at 9:19 p.m. Earl Hawes, 59 Queens Road, appeared before Committee, and concurs with  concerns already mentioned by previous speakers, particularly the development  of sewers in the area.  MINUTES OF THE SPECIAL MEETING OF THE COUNCIL OF THE CORPORATION OF  THE TOWN OF WHITBY HELD ON WEDNESDAY, APRIL 7, 2010 AT THE HOUR OF 7:00  P.M. IN THE MEETING HALL OF THE WHITBY MUNICIPAL BUILDING AS CALLED BY THE  HEAD OF COUNCIL Valerie Skinner, 50 Ward Street, appeared before Committee, and advised that  she is concerned about the amount of farmland being sacrificed to accommodate  this plan and suggested the consultant review ways to preserve farmland if  possible. Carolyn Goodwin, 27 Lakeridge Road, further requested that notice of future  meetings be provided directly to all Almond Village residents. There being no further submissions, the public meeting was closed. A question and answer period ensued. RECOMMENDATION MOVED by Councillor Drumm 1. That Planning Report Item PL 41-10 be received for information; 2. That the Planning Department report back at such time as all public input  and agency comments, have been received and assessed; and 3. That Planning Staff bring forward a recommended Final Official Plan  Amendment for Council's consideration in Committee of the Whole, in  accordance with the requirements of the Planning Act. CARRIED RESOLUTION NO. 126-10 Moved by Councillor Pitchforth Seconded by Councillor Coe That Council rise and ratify the actions from Committee of the Whole.   CARRIED 4. CONFIRMING BY-LAW - BY-LAW NO.6318-10 RESOLUTION NO. 127-10 MOVED by Councillor Coe seconded by Councillor Mitchell that leave be granted to  introduce a by-law and to dispense with the reading of the by-law by the Clerk to  confirm the proceedings of the Council of the Town of Whitby at its special meeting held  MINUTES OF THE SPECIAL MEETING OF THE COUNCIL OF THE CORPORATION OF  THE TOWN OF WHITBY HELD ON WEDNESDAY, APRIL 7, 2010 AT THE HOUR OF 7:00  P.M. IN THE MEETING HALL OF THE WHITBY MUNICIPAL BUILDING AS CALLED BY THE  HEAD OF COUNCIL on April 7h, 2010, and that the same be considered read a first, second and third time and finally passed and that the Mayor and the Clerk sign the same and the Seal of the  Corporation be thereto affixed. CARRIED 5. ADJOURNMENT RESOLUTION NO. 128-10 MOVED by Councillor Drumm Seconded by Councillor Coe That the meeting be adjourned. CARRIED The meeting adjourned at 9:42 p.m. Debi A. Wilcox, Town Clerk Patricia Perkins, Mayor

Heritage Whitby Advisory Committee Minutes  March 8, 2022 - 7:00 PM  Virtual Meeting           Present:  Lynda Armstrong (logged off at 8:20 p.m.)  Laura Bisset, Vice Chair  Margaret Clayton  Karey Anne Large  Paul Rolland  Rick McDonnell  Mark McGowan  Terry Standish      Also Present:  Councillor Newman, Mayor's Designate  Sarah Ferencz, Library Archivist   Lori Tesolin, Supervisor, Policy and Heritage, and Principal Planner   Peter Henley, Staff Liaison, Planner II, Downtown Development  Heather Ellis, Council and Committee Coordinator (Recording  Secretary)    Regrets:  Lynn Collins, Chair  Deanna Hollister  Brian Winter, Honourary Member       Call to Order  1.  Disclosures of Interest    1.1  There were no disclosures of interest.    2.  Approval of Previous Minutes    2.1  Minutes - February 8, 2022      Recommendation:    Moved By Terry Standish    That the Heritage Whitby Advisory Committee minutes of February 8,  2022 be approved.   Heritage Whitby Advisory Committee Minutes   March 08, 2022 - 7:00 PM      Carried  3.  Presentations    3.1  Christy Chrus, Manager, Creative Communities, and Lara Scott,  Program Manager, Events, Culture and Tourism, Town of Whitby  Re: Creative Communities Update: Events Strategy, Culture Plan  Initiatives, and Tourism Strategy  Lara Scott provided an update regarding the Events Strategy, Culture  Plan Initiatives, and Tourism Strategy. Highlights of the presentation  included:  • the four phases of the Special Events Strategy such as situational  analysis and research, municipal comparator review,  consultations and engagement, and strategy development and  action plan;  • a list of 2022 events such as National Indigenous People's Day,  Canada Day, Movies in the Park, Culture Pop-Ups, Christmas in  the Village, and Whitby Lights the Night and Holiday Festival;  • developing a Tourism Strategy by looking at what Whitby has to  offer including food and beverage, specialty retail, arts and  culture, outdoor adventure and recreation, and attractions;  • the Roebuck Street Placemaking pilot project; and,  • the five directions of Whitby's Culture Plan including connecting  creativity, communities, place, stories, and the process.  A question and answer period ensued regarding:  • setting up road signs to notify drivers of the Roebuck Street  closure;  • whether Whitby had an inventory of hospitality space to  accommodate tourists;  • promoting Whitby's uniqueness to attract tourists; and,  • using ambassadors to promote events and engage residents and  tourists.      Recommendation:    Moved By Lynda Armstrong    That the Heritage Whitby Advisory Committee supports a heritage  permit for a temporary road closure of Roebuck Street and the Roebuck  Street Placemaking pilot project.    Page 2 of 4  Heritage Whitby Advisory Committee Minutes   March 08, 2022 - 7:00 PM    Carried  4.  Council Update    4.1  Councillor Newman provided an update regarding:  • the Whitby Sports Complex design;  • a request for a variance to the Town of Whitby Permanent Sign  By-law #7379-18 for 185 Brock Street North;  • the Debrief Report Winter Snow Storm 2022; and,  • establishing a temporary cricket field at Brooklin Memorial Park.  Councillor Newman requested that the Committee consider focusing on  an action plan for 2022.  A brief question and answer period ensued regarding discussion on the  future of Brooklin Memorial Park and Vipond Arena.    5.  Other Business    5.1  Dates of Significance  Rick McDonnell requested feedback from the Committee regarding  establishing a Heritage Day or several dates of significance for Whitby.  Discussion ensued regarding:  • limiting the number of dates recognized;  • considering events that created a 'ripple effect' of importance on  the community such as the establishment of the Dunlop Tire  Plant and its subsequent influence on local economy, industry,  General Motors, and Whitby Sports; and,  • including pre colonial history.      5.2  Sunnycrest Nursing Home  Rick McDonnell stated that the Sunnycrest Nursing Home was closing  and that the original Historic Lick House was incorporated into the  modern building.  Margaret Clayton advised that the property was included on the  Committee's list of Properties of Significance. Laura Bisset requested  that the Committee consider recommending the Town review outdated  resolutions that contravene the Ontario Heritage Act, R.S.O 1990.    6.
